Several actors were featured in their first significant film roles, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold. Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton also appeared early in their careers.
Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her song "Love or Lust," featured in Bill Duke's film, *Deep Cover*. She also sang choruses to many classic West Coast rap songs such as Snoop Dogg's "Gin and Juice" and Dr. Dre's "Let Me Ride".
About 55 percent of undergraduates and 60 percent of all students at the University of Mississippi are from Mississippi. 23 percent are minorities, and international students come from 90 nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet -- Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy starred as Jenny Matrix in the web series Video Game High School from 2012 to 2014. In 2015, Braddy co-starred as Anna Martin in the series Unreal. She is starring as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren (1782–1862) was the eighth President of the United States (1837–41). A member of the Democratic Party, he also served as the eighth Vice President (1833–37) and tenth Secretary of State (1829–31) under Andrew Jackson. He resigned as Secretary of State to aid Jackson in resolving the Petticoat affair and was given a recess appointment as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey is home to Rutgers University-Camden, founded in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States. It is the tenth most populous of the 50 United States, with the 11th most extensive total area. Michigan is the only state to consist of two peninsulas and is one of the leading U.S. states for recreational boating. A U.S. state is a constituent political entity of the United States of America.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s by selling inexpensive, high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction to the mass market through Woolworths and other high street stores for sixpence.
Production of the 2008 film *Australia* took place in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist. *Excuse My French* is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana, and also a 2014 Egyptian film directed by Amr Salama. In 2013, Derek Hough starred in the South Korean-American independent dance film, *Make Your Move*, inspired by Romeo and Juliet.

"Bad Romance" is a song by Lady Gaga from her third extended play, *The Fame Monster* (2009). After a demo leak, the final product was showcased at Alexander McQueen's show at Paris Fashion Week in October 2009. It achieved worldwide success, selling 12 million copies and becoming one of the best-selling singles of all time. *Bad Romance* (film) is a 2011 independent drama film.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including the franchises Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls. Other hits include Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013), and Home (2015). DreamWorks Animation, with Double Dare You, produced the Netflix series Trollhunters, created by Guillermo del Toro.

Chris Eubank (born August 8, 1966) is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. Christopher Livingstone "Chris" Eubank Jr. (born September 18, 1989) is a British professional boxer. He has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015, and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush (born July 8, 1982) is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist. She is known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. James Rupert Jacob Murdoch is the younger son of Rupert Murdoch, the CEO of 21st Century Fox, and chairman of Sky plc. Rupert Murdoch was Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, which split on 28 June 2013, into News Corp and 21st Century Fox.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was the second highest earning actress/model in Israel, behind Bar Refaeli, but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka. Most of her income came from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are usually found by an x-ray, which is a radiographic examination.
The South Wales Coalfield is a large region in south Wales, rich in coal deposits, especially the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football club competition organized by CONCACAF for the top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was first organized in 1962 and was originally known as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 when her eldest son, Edward, ascended the throne. Edward abdicated later that year. She supported her second son, Albert, who succeeded to the throne as George VI, until his death in 1952. Mary died the following year during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
Poseidon grossed $181,674,817 worldwide on a budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first given in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton have the most wins, with three each.

Human trafficking is the trade of humans, most commonly for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. Forced labor, one component of human trafficking, generates an estimated $150 billion in profits annually as of 2014. Of those trafficked, 14.2 million (68%) were exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22%) were sexually exploited, and 2.2 million (10%) were exploited in state-imposed forced labor.
Rio 2 was released on April 11, 2014, and is a sequel to the 2011 film Rio.

Francis I (1708-1765) was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, but his wife held the real power. Francis I (1494-1547) was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death. He was known as François au Grand Nez, the Grand Colas, and the Roi-Chevalier. He formed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with Suleiman the Magnificent. King Francis I of France and Charles V were in conflict during the Italian war of 1536-1538.

Peking University (PKU, Běidà 北大), located in Beijing, is a major Chinese research university and a member of the C9 League. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it was the first modern national university established in China and replaced the ancient Taixue or Guozijian. It is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his appearance, including his friendly mutton chops, his distinctive gravelly voice, and distinctive bass playing style.
Global warming poses a threat to humans, including food security, due to decreasing crop yields and the abandonment of populated areas because of rising sea levels.
Australia is a 2008 Australian-American-British romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.

Michael Dwayne Vick (born June 26, 1980) is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore includes songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices such as traditional food-making and craft-making. Folklore includes oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining. The unit also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones (author) won the 1952 National Book Award for his first published novel, *From Here to Eternity*, which was adapted for film and television. James Jones (basketball player) earned Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He has won three NBA championships, and he and teammate LeBron James reached the NBA Finals for the seventh consecutive year in 2017. He won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
In 1999, the American Film Institute ranked Humphrey Bogart as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the process used for generating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
In 2009, Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE, which went into effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor known for playing the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, longer than any other actor. He narrated the comedy series Little Britain and has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.

Hanford hosts the Columbia Generating Station, a commercial nuclear power plant, and scientific research and development centers, such as the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory. Hanford also has a cleanup project.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior White House official who acts as spokesperson for the executive branch of the United States government administration, especially with regard to the President, senior executives, and policies. The press secretary is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the president. It is a prominent non-Cabinet post.

Kentucky is known as the "Bluegrass State" due to the bluegrass found in its pastures. The Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky houses two of its major cities, Louisville and Lexington. Kentucky is also known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also starred in the films The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper. She was formerly stylized as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, an electronic version of "Despacito" produced by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky were released.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually via pay-per-view television. Starrcade (1985) aired live on closed-circuit television. In 2014, the WWE Network included the previous Starrcades (1983-1986) alongside the rest of the Starrcades in the pay-per-view section. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event.
Veeru Devgan is a Bollywood stunt and action choreographer and film director.
*Star Trek: Discovery* is the first series developed for that service and the first Star Trek series since *Star Trek: Enterprise* concluded in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins. He also played in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

- Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana.
- Excuse My French is a 2014 Egyptian film Comedy directed by Amr Salama.
- Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, also known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.

A floppy disk, also called a floppy, diskette, or disk, is a type of disk storage. It is composed of a thin and flexible magnetic storage medium, sealed in a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric that removes dust particles.
From 1960 to 1996, Guatemala endured a civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, including genocidal massacres of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. Outside of medicine, forceps are usually referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
On Monday, July 11, 2011, the series "The Closer" began its seventh and final season. It had finished its sixth season as cable's highest-rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard is a fictional character and the protagonist of the ABC television series *Lost*, played by Matthew Fox. *Lost* aired on ABC from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, over six seasons, totaling 121 episodes. The first season averaged 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew McConaughey (born November 4, 1969) is an American actor. Since 2011, he has preferred dramatic roles in films such as *The Lincoln Lawyer* (2011), *Bernie* (2011), *Killer Joe* (2011), *The Paperboy* (2012), *Mud* (2012), *Magic Mike* (2012), *The Wolf of Wall Street* (2013), *Dallas Buyers Club* (2013), *Interstellar* (2014), *The Sea of Trees*, and *Free State of Jones* (both 2016). *Mud* (2012 film) stars Matthew McConaughey, Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer is best known for his books, including Deep Blues; his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone; producing blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues; and playing clarinet in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (April 9, 1912 – January 27, 1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. He was best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, in 1941. Gutzon Borglum designed and oversaw the project's execution from 1927-1941 with the help of his son, Lincoln, who took over as leader of the construction project upon his father's death.

The film *Underdog* was directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents provided by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The series "The 100" follows a group of teens, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha, as they return to Earth from a space habitat, "The Ark," after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin, Marcus Kane, and Thelonious Jaha.

The Concert for Bangladesh is recognized as a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project that generated awareness and considerable funds. It also provided valuable lessons and inspiration for projects that followed, notably Live Aid, despite being marred by financial problems.
Mani Ratnam is cited by the media as one of India’s influential filmmakers, widely credited with revolutionising the Tamil film industry and altering the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas at the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton drew especially large numbers of people from neighboring states, as the issue of slavery was of monumental importance to citizens across the nation.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. It stars Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (born October 4, 1941) is an American author of gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her professional writing career with the publication of *Interview with the Vampire* in 1976 and wrote sequels to the novel in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, until his death in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, and the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. In 2010, the city had a population of 77,344. At the beginning of the twentieth century, Camden's population consisted mostly of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film *The Canyons*. *The Canyons* is a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader and written by Bret Easton Ellis.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates were held in seven towns in Illinois.

Homer is the name ascribed by the ancient Greeks to the author of the *Iliad* and the *Odyssey*, two epic poems considered the central works of ancient Greek literature. Joe R. Lansdale is the author of *The Thicket*, a mystery/suspense novel.

Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 – February 2, 2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper. On February 2, 2013, Eddie Ray Routh murdered Kyle at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave consisted of Chris Cornell, Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Wilk was the drummer of Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. Rage Against the Machine was formed in 1991 and consisted of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk. As of 2016, Wilk is playing in the band Prophets of Rage.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. In 2010, Monáe released her first full-length studio album, *The ArchAndroid*, a concept album sequel to her first EP, released by Bad Boy Records.
Mark Helprin wrote the 1983 novel, *Winter's Tale*.

Lake Providence is a town in and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. About 55 percent of the University of Mississippi undergraduates and 60 percent overall come from Mississippi, and 23 percent are minorities; international students come from 90 nations.
In July 2016, the series *Flaked* was renewed for a six-episode second season, scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr was elected twice to the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), served as New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), was a U.S. senator (1791–1797) from New York, and served as vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program. It was first used in 8 unmanned test flights, followed by the first 19 manned launches. The Soyuz spacecraft was designed for the Soviet space program by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s and remains in service today. It succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Ditko studied under Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine broke up due to tensions over the band's direction, prompting de la Rocha to quit and start a solo career. The rest of the band formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, recording three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine announced a reunion and performed together for the first time in seven years. *Renegades* is the fourth studio album by Rage Against the Machine, released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX (S&P Bombay Stock Exchange Sensitive Index), also called the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE), where it is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (SRV), is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is the world's 14th-most-populous country, with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants. Since 2000, Vietnam's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world. Vietnam is one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film that was written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.
Bhagat Singh (23 March 1931) was a socialist revolutionary whose acts of violence against the British and execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the film “Dangal.” “Dangal” is a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) was King of Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death. Scotland and England were individual sovereign states, with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws, though both were ruled by James in personal union. He faced many difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was an original core cast member of the soap opera *Shortland Street* and is known for her roles as Ephiny in *Xena: Warrior Princess*, Cynthia Ross in *The Cult*, and Shota in *Legend of the Seeker*. She also appeared in the film *Separation City* and the series *Rake*. Cormack portrayed Kate Leigh in *Underbelly: Razor* and Bea Smith in the drama *Wentworth*.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer. He is best known for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred and co-starred in the films *Tommy Boy*, *Black Sheep*, *Joe Dirt*, *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*, *Grown Ups*, and *Grown Ups 2*. *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser* is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett (born August 16, 1958) is an American actress.

*Artpop* received mixed reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the United States Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies. It became Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the United States, selling 757,000 copies. The album was the ninth best seller of 2013 with 2.3 million copies worldwide.
In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, *Stadium Arcadium*. He confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

As Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She is lauded as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, even as arguments over Thatcherism persist.

Tom Baker is an English actor who has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative centre. Valencia is Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community is an autonomous community of Spain, and its capital Valencia is the third largest city and metropolitan area in Spain.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
It was announced on April 26, 2012, that *Make It or Break It* had ended and the third season would be the final season. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies that enables the recognition and translation of spoken language into text by computers. It is used in voice user interfaces such as voice dialing, call routing, domotic appliance control, search, simple data entry, preparation of structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft. Companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC use deep learning methods in designing and deploying speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf was an American businessman and co-founder of the San Diego Comic-Con International, which he chaired starting in 1970. The San Diego Comic-Con was originally founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group that included Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. Later, it was called the "San Diego Comic Book Convention".
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee.

Dubuisson (France) and Van Zyl (South Africa) tied at 16 under par. McIlroy and Kiradech Aphibarnrat were 15 under par. McIlroy is bidding to win his first title since May and his third Race to Dubai title in four years. Chris Wood (-13) and Richard Bland (-12) are fifth and seventh, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman stated that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government needed to offer "concrete solutions" and that they wanted someone who could speak for the royal family. He acknowledged that many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties, but believed working with reformists within the royal family was the only way forward. He noted that hours before GCC troops came in on March 14, 2011, a seven-point plan towards a constitutional monarchy had been agreed upon with the crown prince. Sheikh Salman expressed hope that US Secretary of State John Kerry would "do more than his predecessor" and urged the UK government to speak out publicly. He reiterated al-Wefaq's position to continue calling for "peaceful demonstrations" and called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists.

Christopher Hogwood, a conductor and one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement, died at his home in Cambridge following an illness lasting several months. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for some 30 years. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. Hogwood was also the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University.

For the year ending in March, 57 homicide victims were recorded, the lowest number in a 12-month period since 1976. As of March 31, 2016, only one case from 2015-16 was unresolved. Sharp instruments were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides (29 cases), with knives involved in 26 of those cases. While most of the accused had an unknown status for alcohol and drugs, 31% (20 people) were identified as being under the influence. The number of homicide victims for 2014-15 was later increased to 62 after three cases were reclassified following deaths.

The Cherries lost 2-1 at Sunderland on Saturday, becoming the first team to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League this season. Dan Gosling's goal was their first for three games. Bournemouth were unable to find an equaliser against 10 men following Steven Pienaar's dismissal. Howe stated that "Sometimes football pans out that way and you have to accept it. It's how you move on from that which is key."

Mr. Abbott stated that stopping the boats is the only way to prevent deaths at sea, referencing Australia's policy of detaining migrants and resettling them elsewhere. He also said that the image of Syrian three-year-old Alan Kurdi, who died trying to reach Greece by boat, was "very sad". The New York Times criticized Australia's policy as "brutal," "inhumane, of dubious legality and strikingly at odds with the country's tradition of welcoming people fleeing persecution and war". Mr. Abbott angered Jewish groups by saying Islamic State (IS) was worse than the Nazis, leading to condemnation from The Executive Council of Australian Jewry Robert Goot, who called the comments "injudicious and unfortunate". Mr. Abbott later said he stood by his comments, but that he was not in the "business of ranking evil".

Washington blamed Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians and suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia established to sustain the cessation of hostilities. The US warned it would halt talks unless Moscow stopped bombing Aleppo, where hundreds of people have died since government forces launched an offensive to take full control of the city after a week-long truce lapsed. Russia said it regretted the US move, accusing it of shifting the blame for the collapse of last month's truce. Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said Washington did not fulfil the key condition of the agreement to improve the humanitarian condition around Aleppo.

Policy Exchange, a think tank, proposed selling high-value social homes to raise £4.5bn annually, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes. They believe this would create the largest social house building programme since the 1970s. Downing Street backed the report, stating councils should efficiently use their social housing stock. Labour opposed, suggesting it would drive out low-wage families. Critics argue it would push less well-off individuals out of expensive areas. Housing Minister Grant Shapps mentioned the government's "radical reforms," including a £19.5bn investment in affordable housing.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died last week at his home in Swansea, where there have been 942 cases of measles. An examination was unable to establish whether measles was the main cause of his death, and further tests are needed. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have needed hospital treatment. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated at Swansea's Morriston Hospital for asthma, and a few days later, he became unwell and developed a rash. He was found dead at his flat on April 18th.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence on a boy under the age of 16 that was reported to have taken place in 2001. He is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court, Cumbria Police said.

Neil Aspin's promotion-chasing hosts have not lost in nine National League matches, while Adam Lockwood's side are unbeaten in five. Guiseley went ahead on 15 minutes when a throw-in found James Hurst who squared to Jake Lawlor. Gateshead levelled on 62 minutes when a slip by half-time substitute Derek Asamoah let York curl sweetly into the top-right corner from the edge of the box. The match ended with a score of Gateshead 1, Guiseley 1.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands at the football club, increasing capacity. This was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Shareholder Steve Lansdown stated that if there is no judicial review by March, redevelopment will begin in May.

Cuadrilla suspended drilling after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, and will examine data before deciding whether to resume. The BGS said the tremor on 1 April shared a "similar location and mechanism". Fracking involves shattering rocks underground to release gas. Mark Miller, chief executive of Cuadrilla Resources, said they have stopped fracking operations to consult with authorities and experts. The BGS said it was also monitoring fracking as a precaution, and that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes. Dr. Brian Baptie of the BGS said the earthquake was felt in Poulton-Le-Fylde, and analysis placed the epicenter within 2km of the Preese Hall site.

Angus Carpenter, 62, of Liverpool, denied three counts of fraud and was found guilty of one count when he played with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015. He was cleared of the two other counts. Carpenter claimed the banner was a tribute to the victims, not an attempt to deceive anyone. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0. Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence scored for Ipswich. Sandro of QPR hit the post with a header. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance, while QPR boss Ian Holloway expressed disappointment, particularly with his team's response after the second goal, and stated his players need to be mentally tougher. The win moved Ipswich to 14th place, and QPR slipped to 15th.

Wells, 23, scored 373 runs at 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66 in the T20 Blast last season. Wells stated that the club is going in the right direction, and the coaches have created an environment of elite performance.

The Reds beat third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for a second win in a row. Churcher told BBC Cornwall that the front row and front five made 70-plus tackles in the game. The Reds face seven teams who are below them in the table in their next eight games, as well as league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher believes his side still has a lot of room for improvement.

Nazrul, also called Nazu, a 28-year-old man, was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata and is alleged to be the person who raped the 74-year-old nun. The incident occurred on March 14 in Ranaghat town. Police have identified eight suspects, with six arrested and two still untraced. All five previously arrested have named Nazrul as the rapist. In May, police arrested Milon Sarkar and described him as the leader of the gang. During the attack, money was stolen, and the building was ransacked.

This interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains why we change what we buy. The domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports impacted the items on sale and popular with UK consumers. The video explores how ownership and ranking of some of the biggest UK brands are changing. A non-interactive version is available for older browsers.

Two incidents occurred, one on September 15th and another seven days later, where individuals were tricked by someone claiming to be from BT technical support. The scammer gained remote access to the victims' computers and stole money. PC Siobhan Pellett urged people to be careful with cold calls and never give out banking details or account numbers over the phone, as banks and reputable businesses never ask for this information.

Duffy, 37, has joined Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. Mark Campbell, chairman, said "He is a fantastic coach and we are very excited to see how his reign here unfolds." Duffy was replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.

At 12:50 GMT on Sunday, a Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach. A rider, found unconscious on wet sand with head injuries and very cold, was treated and subsequently flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, a decision was made to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system. The deal will enable satellites to receive transmissions that aircraft currently only send to other aircraft and to ground stations, allowing "real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world." The disappearance of flight MH370, which is believed to have crashed into the southern Indian Ocean, exposed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. The UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU) responded in record time to the expectations of the global community on global flight tracking. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, was found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez was arrested and is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. He is also charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license. The FBI confirmed the boy's identity after receiving a tip on October 30.

Following a fire on 2 March, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and revoked its environmental permit. The company has until 7 August to appeal the decision. GMFRS visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months and found the site operators, Asset and Land, to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety legislation. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, proposed two bills: one to allow territories to join Russia via referendum or leader plea, and another to expedite Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians. The passport bill eliminates requirements such as state tax, previous Russian residence, sufficient funds, and renouncing Ukrainian citizenship, allowing applications at Russian diplomatic missions with a reduced waiting period. These bills are linked to the Ukraine crisis, particularly in Crimea, where pro-Russian sentiments are strong. Several Russian MPs have also visited Crimea, including former Olympic ice skating champion Irina Rodnina, former cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova and heavyweight boxer Nikolai Valuev.

The team has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. McLaren's slump started in 2013, when they lost their way on chassis design but still had the best engine. Currently, the team has improved the car, but the problems lie with the Honda power-unit. McLaren's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline, with their first title in 1974 and another in 1976. Ron Dennis took control and led the team to domination in 1984-5, followed by partnerships with Honda and Mercedes. Dennis insists that it is only a matter of time before success will return and that McLaren will be the next team to win the title after Mercedes.

Thomas Baker, 44, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, two aged 29 and the other 32, remain in police custody. Police are searching for a silver VW polo that left the scene at speed. Officers are seeking witnesses who may have information key to their inquiries.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining the request to take over 250 hectares of common land for a circuit, with backers offering around 320 hectares of replacement land. There are conflicting accounts about whether the circuit would damage habitats and plant life. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, and Welsh government ministers will have the final say.

Chechen Muslim clerics stated that a report by Novaya Gazeta insulted their faith and Chechen men, declaring that "retribution will catch up with the true instigators." The paper reported on April 1st that over 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report. A spokeswoman for the LGBT Network said detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun. Kadyrov denied the allegations, and his spokesman Alvi Karimov said there were no gay people in Chechnya. Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev confirmed that "retribution" was part of the resolution adopted at the special Muslim meeting. Investing Solutions, a letting agent, makes a profit by placing multiple unrelated people in one house and charging housing benefit for each person. They work with the charity Fresh Start Housing, which finds clients from London homeless charities. Records show that Samir Patel set up Investing Solutions in 2002 and Fresh Start Housing in 2010. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, operating across seven London boroughs. In one example, Investing Solutions claimed £2,114 per month in housing benefit for two tenants while paying the property owner £1,150, resulting in an annual gross profit of £11,568 on that property. Wandsworth Council in south London has paid the lettings agency more than £2.1m. Fresh Start Housing stated it had housed 788 homeless people since it was founded and 222 in the last 12 months.

In a Eurobasket qualifying campaign, Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13. Coach Joe Prunty's team lost to the Dutch, who were led by Worthy De Jong with 18 points. Prunty was pleased with Gordon's contribution. GB will play in Hungary in midweek.

On Wednesday, the former five-weight world champion submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) regarding glove size for the upcoming bout. NAC rules require 10oz gloves for fights at 154 lbs, but lighter gloves could lead to more punishing punches. The NAC will debate the matter on August 16th. NAC executive director Bob Bennett stated that the primary concern is the health and safety of the fighters. Bennett also shared several reasons to approve the fight after gathering information, including feedback on McGregor's sparring sessions. Joe Cortez, a Hall of Fame official, was hired to oversee McGregor's sparring sessions.

Fleet Street was once the center of British journalism, with the first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, published there in 1702. At its height, nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers had offices there. However, media tycoon Rupert Murdoch moved his papers off Fleet Street in 1986, and by 1988, most national newspapers had followed suit. The Dundee-based Sunday Post is closing its London office, and its reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, are leaving. Mr. Smith is becoming a freelance journalist, while Mr. Sherriff is writing his memoirs.

The Harry Potter author stated that she believes in standing up to bullies and feels no responsibility to hush up that kind of behavior to protect the image of any political party. She faced criticism after donating £1m to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum and previously donated the same amount to the Labour party in 2008. The SNP is now the third-largest party in the UK.

The University of Edinburgh's School of Law published findings from the Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime in the Scottish Justice Matters journal. The study found that children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action and about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than better-off children who commit the same crime. Poverty increases the risks of violence, and contact with the juvenile justice system increases the risks associated with poverty. A Scottish government spokesman said Scotland is becoming a safer place to live.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and was remanded in custody. Two other men were released without charge. Det Sgt Padraig Frawley alleged that Mr. Walsh and two others were looking for Mr. Haugh, and a fight ensued where weapons were used. Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back and was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. Police recovered a knife handle and a blade with blood on it at the scene. Mr. Walsh was remanded in custody until August 14.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted that Tom Elliott might reveal how many people he harassed and shot as a member of the UDR. The tweet was deleted within an hour. Mr. Elliott, who served in the UDR between 1982 and 1992, has a clear MoD record. Mr. Justice Stevens has reserved judgement on the amount of compensation. Mr. Elliott stated he has been totally vindicated.

Hawick Knitwear has increased its production of sweaters to 9,500 each week from about 7,500 last year due to increased demand. The company, which dates back to 1874, was bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November of last year. The increase in production is in direct response to a surge in orders from both home and abroad for private label clients and the company's own brand. Hawick Knitwear employs more than 230 staff.

Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, told Luton Crown Court that he had been blinded by the setting sun when he struck Sylvia Blackburn, 72, outside Bedford Road Lower School last December. Mrs. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now being treated in residential care. Mr. Wright denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr. Wright's eyes. The trial continues.

In response to increased Russian submarine patrols, a NATO exercise involving 10 warships, anti-submarine warfare helicopters, and underwater drones is underway to find a German U-boat, U33. The exercise highlights Britain's defensive gap due to its lack of maritime patrol aircraft. U33's task is to evade detection and target the command ship, USS Vicksburg, and an oil tanker. Rear Admiral Brad Williamson emphasizes the importance of this training, given recent reports of Russian submarines near Sweden, Finland, and the UK. Lieutenant Colin Ryan notes the difficulty of locating submarines. Russia has been investing heavily in its submarine fleet, now possessing around 60 submarines.

Since violence escalated in South Sudan in July, 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, exceeding the number of refugees from any other country this year, including Syria. An average of 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees daily, escaping ethnic violence, killings, and rape. Testimonies from refugees like Nelson Ladu Thomas and Otima Amos highlight the targeting of civilians along ethnic lines. Uganda is struggling with the influx, with the UNHCR's Nasir Abel Fernandes calling it a "massacre of civilians." The Bidi Bidi refugee settlement has rapidly grown to house over a quarter of a million people.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle on November 12 for the English super-middleweight championship. He became a professional boxer in 2013 and has a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights. McKenzie is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital will receive money as part of the coalition's £330m investment for new NHS facilities across England. The £33m project will provide a new hospital with 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated. NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust will pay for the remaining balance. Somerset PCT hopes to build the new hospital on land at Bowers Lane, with completion aimed for autumn 2014.

The victim was fatally injured outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe. Police were called to the scene at about 13:35 GMT, where they found the man with a gunshot wound to his chest. He was taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents said the man was a member of a family who live close to the scene and that relatives had been gathering for a family celebration when the attack occurred.

The most prominent pro-Ukrainians hackers are the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin. They use distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, target accounts to disrupt separatist funding, and have hacked into public CCTV systems. Cyber Berkut is an anti-Western group that aims at thwarting Ukraine's military plans. During US Vice-President Joe Biden's visit to Kiev, Cyber Berkut hacked several Ukrainian government websites. Russian activist group Anonymous International published leaked documents from the Kremlin. In May, it leaked emails to and from former Russian FSB colonel Igor Girkin.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional after Alex Salmond and Duncan McNeil bid farewell to the parliament. Mr. Salmond, who served as first minister between 2007 and 2014, stated that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse". Ms. Marwick thanked Mr. Salmond for his contributions as an MSP and as first minister. Mr. McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also bowing out of Holyrood.

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is calling on pensioners, their friends, and families to share their experiences of residential care to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. As part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales, she will highlight good care and the impact of poor care. The commissioner will review whether older people living in residential care have a good quality of life, and her team will speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, said his group supported the overall aims of the review but was disappointed that the commissioner had not included a provider expert on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group's pre-tax profit increased by £800,000 to £3.5m, despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m. International sales grew in Europe and new markets. The company manufactures and supplies feeds for various sectors and has 19 shops across Scotland. The impact of Brexit is still to be fully understood.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden on Saturday afternoon, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker. He is described as white, about 6ft (1.8m) tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. Police have urged anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, stated that the IMF's latest reading of the global economy shows a weakening baseline and that we are at a delicate juncture. The IMF has said it is likely to downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when it next releases its economic predictions in April.

Council leader Dave Stewart said the Cowes crossing would be free until July 2 "in recognition of the problems" and to allow feedback. He said the council had ordered a review of the project by auditors and that it had been a "frustrating and disappointing start" to the ferry. Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation for local businesses was up for discussion, and that ramp extensions were authorized to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete. He also said groundings were an issue with seamanship, which had been resolved.

A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene of a multi-vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at about 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening while officers investigated.

Matching Models, an international temp agency, describes itself as "an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called its advertisement for a personal assistant "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women". The agency's founder Nathalie Jansen said: "Our clients are important to us - and looks are important." Employment lawyer James Lynas, partner at Winckworth Sherwood, said the advert was "clearly unlawful". Under the 2010 Equality Act, it is against the law to say, or imply, that you will discriminate against anyone.

The shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, worked as an office assistant in the school. He allegedly barged into the room of 18-year-old Gautami and shot her in the head. He then shot another student, Sirisha, who is now believed to be out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday and remanded until April 12.

Glaad analyzed shows between June 2016 and May 2017, counting 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also found a record-high percentage of black characters on broadcast television. Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis stated that while progress was made, numbers were "only part of the story".

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not stand for re-election. This decision followed criticism over a £10.25m loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council, when he was leader, that is now missing. A police investigation is looking into "alleged financial irregularities". Mr. Mackintosh has denied any wrongdoing.

Roy Oliver, 37, fired a rifle into a car driving away from a party, killing Jordan Edwards, 15. He was sacked a few days later for policy violations. Oliver was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official. He faces five to 99 years in prison on the murder charge and would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas county since 1973. He is currently free on bail.

Mrs. Trump and Barron will move to Washington after he finishes school, a decision that has garnered both criticism and support, with some noting it is not unusual for children to finish the school year. Historically, only two other First Ladies have not resided in the White House during their husbands' terms. First Ladies often balance ceremonial duties with personal priorities and causes, and Melania Trump has indicated her focus will be on Barron and tackling cyber-bullying. Some First Ladies have taken on active public roles, while others, like Nancy Reagan, initially focused on supporting their husbands. The White House family life can be surprisingly normal, with past families like the Clintons and Obamas emphasizing family time and privacy.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October this year. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) has been asked to investigate the initial police response to a call from the man, who was later found dead. Police Scotland said it was "fully engaging" with the investigation. A report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) in due course.

Gusts of up to 75mph (120kmph) could occur, particularly to the west of the mountains, with the unusual easterly direction potentially adding to the impact of the winds. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea was likely. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. The Giants' Derrick Walser opened the scoring, but Jeff Dimmen leveled. Mike Forney and Andy Bohmback scored to make it 2-1. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored before Nottingham's David Ling got one back. The teams meet again on Saturday. World champion Hamilton started from the back, had a broken front wing on lap one, and did five pit stops. Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen, who finished fifth. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, with a number of collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car on lap four. Ricciardo suffered a left-rear puncture on lap three, allowing Rosberg to pass. Mercedes decided not to stop Rosberg under the safety car, and he drove off into the distance when the race re-started on lap nine.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality, receiving praise from former teammates and leading figures in German football administration, including former German Football Association president Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball. This announcement is considered a watershed moment in Germany. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman Steffen Seibert and openly gay German politician Volker Beck also praised Hitzlsperger. Zwanziger expressed optimism that this would lead to greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, helping the Seagulls achieve promotion to the top flight. His contract is due to expire at the end of the campaign, but he hopes to sign a new deal. He signed a one-year deal with Brighton in June 2016. Sidwell told BBC Radio Sussex that he has given himself every opportunity to earn a new deal.

Blackpool and Colchester United finished 1-1. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool after 12 minutes, and Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester after 17 minutes. Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a chance to win 15 minutes before the end. Colchester's Sean Murray was shown a red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time, leaving Colchester with 10 men. The match ended with multiple fouls, substitutions, and yellow cards for players from both teams.

Reid, 29, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season. He could debut for the U’s in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

Following PC Keith Palmer's murder, The UK Police Memorial Trust appealed for £1.5m towards the construction of a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019 and will be dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of officers who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. The government committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial.

United remain 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. Ferguson stated that the focus is good and the only thing that matters is to win your next game. He will make changes for Monday's FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea after seeing Rafael and Anderson suffer injuries at Sunderland, while goalkeeper David De Gea also suffered a knock after a heavy collision with team-mate Nemanja Vidic.

Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Mr. Schmidt stated that the company did what was "legally required" to pay the right amount of taxes and that it is up to the government to change its tax system. Margaret Hodge suggested a new committee should be established to oversee major firms' tax arrangements. EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities."

NHS Improvement wants to reduce the £3.6bn spent on agency staff last year by £1bn by the end of this financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far. NHS trusts are 10% down on where they wanted to be. NHS Improvement chief executive Jim Mackey said, "The NHS simply doesn't have the money to keep forking out for hugely expensive agency staff. There's much more to be done."

The Longford Town Centre stands as a monument to the end of the Celtic Tiger and the Republic of Ireland's economic crash. Local traders like Matt O'Brien, who runs a family-owned men's clothing shop, are starting to see the beginnings of an economic recovery. Fianna Fáil, the main opposition party, argues that the government should spend money on broadband improvement instead of water meters. The government says it is doing its bit for County Longford, with the recent announcement that Center Parcs hopes to employ about 1,000 people at its planned tourism development in Ballymahon. Traders like O'Brien believe more could be done to boost local business, such as free parking.

The competition concludes on May 29th, featuring eight teams. The top four teams will qualify for the play-offs. BBC Sport provides scores, fixtures, and results. Leading run-scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249), with Warner and De Villiers tied for most sixes (12). Top wicket-takers include McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7). Four current or former England players—Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen—will participate. Fixtures and results are listed from April 25th to the final on May 29th.

The number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013. Many bags are not recyclable and often end up in rubbish dumps and rivers, causing environmental problems. From October, people in England will have to pay 5p for plastic bags to encourage reuse. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have seen a decrease in bags used where people are charged.

A yellow 'be aware' warning for wind was in force across Wales until midnight on Friday. The highest gusts of wind were recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey. Part of a school roof was ripped off at Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, and hundreds of homes across Wales experienced power cuts. There were train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and Irish Ferries cancelled six of its fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham. Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed to Tuesday, 27 December.

Jordan was "super excited" and wanted "to put a different spin on it". He is looking forward to working with Ryan Coogler, Nyong'o, and Chadwick Boseman. Nyong'o won a best supporting actress Oscar in 2014. Black Panther will be released in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, is hoped to reopen in 2018 and be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. The theatre and studios are part of a larger east wing restoration project costing £26.6m to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) is contributing £18.8m, Haringey Council is contributing £6.8m, and Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust is committed to raising the final £1m by summer 2017.

James Milner, 30, won 61 caps for England and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped their burning house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, thanks to her son David, who was the only one awake and saw the flames. The house was destroyed, and the family pets did not survive. The fire started from rubbish burned in the wood stove, and the fire alarm did not go off. The community has rallied behind the family, donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for her son.

Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010, valuing the club at £105m, and now own over 85% of the club. Last year, Sullivan stated a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold intended the ownership to pass on to their children. Since August's move to London Stadium, West Ham have been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups.

"This is definitely not the Oscars," said Jillian Bell on the red carpet in Los Angeles. The night's big winner was *The Fault in Our Stars,* which won best movie, and Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance in *American Sniper*, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance in *22 Jump Street*, and Meryl Streep for best villain in *Into the Woods*. Robert Downey Jr. brought his fellow Avengers stars to their knees while accepting the Generation Award. Clips from upcoming releases were shown.

The Dons loaned 21-year-old Smith to United in July, and he has five goals this season. Smith made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. St Mirren boss Jack Ross said that Smith is a good, mature player and will give the team another option in the attacking area. St Mirren will host Falkirk on Saturday.

The Northumberland County Council said its Jetpatcher machines can now tackle potholes due to the warm weather. Over the next four months, the council hopes to fill in 145 potholes each day. Extra staff will also be repairing drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clearing debris from gutters.

Last December on EnQuest's Thistle platform, rigging supervisor Steve Innes and fellow Wood Group contractors were exposed to alpha radiation during planned shutdown work. They were told there was a problem two-thirds of the way through the trip and that they had been working without proper PPE. EnQuest stated that the exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), and additional precautionary steps have been taken. Wood Group emphasized their commitment to employee safety and conducted medical assessments. Unite union expressed concerns about the treatment of the workers, while the HSE confirmed the incident was not reportable under the RIDDOR system.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased the sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari in 2007 for $650,000 (£420,000) from Art of the Past. The manager of the company later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The ACM will return the sculpture to India following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The museum will take legal action to get compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km. It was felt as far away as Milan and Florence, with aftershocks felt across a large area. Phone lines and power supplies were down in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated in the immediate vicinity. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, saw results after being dubious about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate. The fruit is still attached to the plant and is not yet ripe enough to eat.

The release of Rockstar's open-world adventure game has been delayed until March 24, requiring a few extra weeks of testing and polish. Online heists will be coming to consoles before the PC release date. Screenshots from the PC version of GTA V have been released, promising greater levels of detail, and will be visible in 1080p at 60fps, with up to 4K resolution and support for up to triple monitor configurations. Minimum specifications required to run GTA V have also been published. Grand Theft Auto V became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1bn in revenue in three days.

Simpson, a 76-year-old artist, won the £25,000 prize for his painting *Squint (19)*. It depicts a leper squint, which Simpson described as "holes made in the sides of medieval churches so the undesirables could look through to the service and somehow take part". Judge Ansel Krut said the work was "quite extraordinary". Simpson plans to spend the prize money on art supplies. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards.

Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit offices were attacked, with no casualties reported. Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, and firefighters quickly extinguished the blaze. The attacks happened almost at the same time, early on Thursday, and windows in both buildings were shattered by gunfire. Police found numerous spent bullet casings at both scenes and are hunting the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

A 24-year-old, ex-Burton player, under contract with the Stags, has reached an agreement to join Marcus Bignot's side on a free transfer, officially joining on January 1. He scored three goals in 23 appearances while on loan at Crawley. He is Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Wenger, whose club contract runs to the summer, has been linked to Southgate's job. Southgate succeeded Sam Allardyce in September. Wenger said Southgate "has accumulated experiences and is a good observer of what's going on in the national team." Wenger added that 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin would be offered a new contract by the club. Wenger added that midfielder Aaron Ramsey, 25, will miss "one or two" more games.

A local man fell from a cherry picker at Fruehauf on Houghton Road at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are carrying out a joint inquiry, and the company is cooperating fully.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf said a new charter arrangement would resolve the long-running dispute over seafarers' pay, where some workers on two freight boats were reportedly paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will see contracted-out services return to operator Serco Northlink next month. The new charter basis will allow the wage issue to be resolved, and all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, Samantha, 57. The two men had a confrontation and were separated by members of the public. Mr. Mitchell and his mother also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter known as The Invisible Man, died at 66 after battling cancer. He wrote hits such as Off The Wall, Baby Be Mine, Boogie Nights, and Thriller. Temperton traced his songwriting ability back to his father's influence. He won a Grammy Award in 1990 for his work on Birdland and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986 for his work on the soundtrack for The Color Purple. Many musicians paid tribute to him, including Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, and Gilles Peterson.

A team including Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott of Swansea University have discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon. The earthworks, called "geoglyphs," are unlikely to be villages and may have been used as ritual gathering places. Researchers found evidence suggesting the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may retain a strong legacy of ancient "agroforestry" practices to this day, and that the geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation.

The Australian, 21, ranked 12th in the world, beat world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to progress to the second round. Kyrgios won the Japan Open on Sunday and stated he was feeling very tired. Last year, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 (£984) for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters.

The HPV jab will protect against head and neck cancers. The Welsh government stated it is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation regarding potentially extending the vaccination program. Charities and organizations will deliver a letter to the Welsh government calling for the vaccination to be rolled out, as HPV causes 5% of the global cancer burden. In 2008, a vaccination program was rolled out in schools, and 85% of girls in Wales have been vaccinated.

Jak Trueman, 15, who was suffering from a rare form of blood cancer, passed away. His mother, Allison, announced his death on Facebook. Jak had been documenting his life and treatment on social media since his diagnosis in August, attracting over 28,000 Likes on his Facebook page, "Jak's Journey." He briefly attended a school prom held in his honor on Saturday. On January 23, Jak and his family learned that his cancer had spread, and doctors decided not to pursue further treatment. In the days following, Jak's family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0, with Abdallah El Said scoring the winning goal, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside. Egypt's victory keeps them in contention for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament. Earlier, Ghana secured their quarter-final place by beating Mali 1-0. Key events include missed attempts, substitutions for both teams, and fouls.

Lancashire County Council has identified land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station. Skelmersdale's original railway station closed in 1956. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County councillor John Fillis stated the preferred location allows for future expansion, has good highway access, and good connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The council will now start acquiring the relevant land.
A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene of an elaborate grow house in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. Plants were found during the search.

A 28-year-old woman was found lying on a pavement with serious injuries and underwent an emergency operation. She was dragged by the neck through several streets. The woman's ex-partner, a 38-year-old man, later handed himself in to authorities. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. Police have secured the area where the woman was found and called for witnesses. The motive for the attack is not yet clear.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin looked at 4,600 workers and found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are 25% less likely to get one. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. There were differences according to age, with women and men under 40 both asking for and receiving pay rises at the same rate.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a suitable new burial site for many years but has run out of suitable land within Oxford. The council said it had not given up and was "still exploring options". Two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. After that, only the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes would be possible.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22, will be able to use an app to trigger online information, including videos and band interviews. The app will offer an augmented reality experience, allowing people around the world to interact with the festival. The message will be updated in the run-up to and during HebCelt, allowing people to access information and interviews, buy tickets, and get a taste of the festival.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before and showed no symptoms on Saturday.

In 2004, a 15-year-old girl was raped by Davina Ayrton, who was known as David Ayrton at the time. The defendant, now 34, denied the charge. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody and said she would likely be held at a male prison. Protocols have been put in place for her detention. Ayrton will be sentenced on March 4.

The Serbs lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. The day before, Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. In July, the 29-year-old, 12-time Grand Slam winner was defeated by American Sam Querrey at Wimbledon. Before the Olympics, he won his 30th Masters title in Toronto. You can subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter to receive news, features, and video.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US will compete in Saturday's event in Carrbridge. Competitors can only use chainsaws to carve logs into shapes of animals and people. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old, has been recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in September but is now "back up and running." He is aiming for a return at the beginning of February, potentially a couple of weeks earlier if the physios agree. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union.

On Tuesday morning, border agents encountered two men near Sumas, Washington, interrupting an attempt to smuggle MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately taken into custody. The other, Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, fled and was later arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department in British Columbia. The backpacks carried by Hall and Laviolette contained 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy. Investigators later arrested Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert for their alleged involvement in the smuggling operation. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service counseled more than 4,500 children in the past year, compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. Online trolls cause misery and humiliation for thousands of children, and cyber-bullying follows them home, becoming a persecution they cannot escape. Dame Esther Rantzen said that adults, parents, and teachers must intervene, and schools must take this problem seriously. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance.

The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot at the request of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office to avoid straining relations with Washington before US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The US chose not to veto a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Netanyahu. The settlements are considered illegal under international law, though Israel disputes this. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution "paves the way" for the upcoming conference on Middle East peace in France on January 15.

The Queen's 90th birthday is being marked with a series of events, including the release of a picture for stamps featuring four generations of the Royal Family. The Queen visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office to mark the 500th anniversary of the postal service.
