Prince William stated the Queen has been a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be. Ten stamps have been released to celebrate the Queen's birthday. On Thursday, the Queen and Prince Philip will walk around Windsor, unveil a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway, and light a beacon, initiating a series of over 900 beacons worldwide. On Friday, the Obamas will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle.

After Cheltenham Town's bright start, West Ham United's Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored two quick goals, giving the Premier League side control before half-time. Cheltenham Town's best chance came with Harry Pell's low volley, but Dan Holman could not get the required touch. West Ham could have won by a greater margin, but Jonathan Flatt stopped Sakho, and Kyle Storer cleared Angelo Ogbonna's header. The match ended with Cheltenham Town 0, West Ham United 2. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

Andreas Werner, 46, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. He failed to spot motorcyclist Aidan McNicholl, 36, as he turned his VW Transporter right, causing the fatal crash. The victim's family saw no value in Werner being sent to jail.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, west London, is facing a possible life prison term for his role in Syria's battlefields. He left the UK in January of last year and joined Rayat al Tawheed, a group of fighters affiliated with Islamic State. He posted videos and pictures of his personal jihad, appealed for donations, and created video diaries of fighters' lives. Khawaja faked his own death with an online obituary before attempting to reenter Britain unnoticed. He was apprehended by police at Dover and has admitted to four offenses. Tahir Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Khawaja was held in a special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at London's maximum security Belmarsh prison.

Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season as Wrexham finished eighth in the table. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham.

National Trust volunteers have been clearing away sealed bottles that arrived at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard, which are believed to have come from a container that went overboard from a ship during stormy weather. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency said there is no current evidence that the bottles are from the MV Blue Ocean, which lost a container with bottles of 'Vanish' near Land's End in May. Cornwall Wildlife Trust said it was "highly concerned" about the impact on "sensitive marine life." Cornwall Council advised the public to keep children and dogs away from the bottles.

The incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00. Several people received minor injuries in the crash, the road was closed, and diversions were put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland said inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, 28, made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson said Dervite made an "excellent contribution" towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is one of several players signing new contracts with Bolton, following their promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything," while Baroness Smith said his party was giving people "false hope." The two parties had previously cooperated on Brexit issues but disagreed when MPs rejected amendments. A Labour source called the Lib Dems' actions "fairly obvious grandstanding," and the Lib Dems accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans." Despite this, Baroness Ludford stated that the Liberal Democrats would continue to collaborate with peers on issues where they have agreement. However, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions."

In this election, defence is a low priority for most political parties, despite the world becoming more dangerous. Opinion polls show defence is low on the list of electorate concerns. The UK has been reducing its armed forces, with the regular Army being reduced from 102,000 to 82,000, and the Royal Navy has only 19 warships. The UK has fallen to sixth place in defence spending globally. There is no commitment to spend 2% of GDP on defence, with projections suggesting a fall to 1.7% by the end of the decade. Further cuts are likely, with the Ministry of Defence (MoD) potentially losing another £2bn-£3bn annually. Key policy decisions revolve around renewing Britain's nuclear deterrent, with varying stances among parties. The UK is also getting two new aircraft carriers, but there are concerns about crewing and equipping them.

Barcelona stated they had not committed any offense in the signing of Neymar, despite a judge in Spain ruling there was sufficient evidence against them to continue investigations into the transfer. Barca paid £48.6m for Neymar, but with additional costs, the total cost will be £106.8m. The club denied any tax-related crime and made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to defend the club's reputation. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches.

Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, died as a passenger in a van that was hit by a Mazda Premacy being driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Mr. Luciw's family and colleague Andy Harrington, who sustained serious injuries in the crash, believe that retired drivers should have to undergo regular driving tests or medical examinations. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must fill in a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) said it had no plans to restrict licensing on the basis of age. Age UK said it was "vital" older people could drive for as long as possible.

Alison Britton, a professor of healthcare and medical law, will examine the final report on the safety of implants used to treat incontinence. The report concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely and recommended patients be offered a range of treatments and be given information to make "informed choices." It also recommended mandatory reporting of adverse events. Two patients quit the original review group in protest, and consultant also quit the expert group over concerns about the final draft of the report. Tracey Gillies, chairwoman of the independent review, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the review's controversial final report.

Muir, 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan raised concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria for record-breaking attempts, but British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. If there is no doping control at an event where a British record is set, there is no requirement for the athlete to submit drug tests. McColgan believes Muir has the ability to get down to 14.30 and can win world medals.

Jung won aboard Sam, with France's Astier Nicolas taking silver and American Phillip Dutton winning bronze. William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, and Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. You can find out how to get into equestrian with a special guide and subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter for news, features, and video.

The Briton, 30, won 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Johanna Konta reached the second week for the first time with a 6-4 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari of Greece. Fognini, 30, was within sight of a fifth set, which would have required the roof to be brought across or both men to return on Saturday. From 5-2 down, Murray showed his fighting qualities to save set points in three consecutive games.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven on October 6, 2014, at 06:00 BST for a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar, with receipts showing alcohol being served as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill was charged with two counts of allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours, and James Thomas faced one count of the same charge. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Ms. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt said: "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." He denied having any regrets about his remarks regarding transferring to the SDLP, stating he would rather go into Stormont Castle with the SDLP than Sinn Féin. He emphasized the election was about "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption". The Ulster Unionist's manifesto is entitled 'Real Partnership'.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion, dubbed 'Turing's Law,' will go before the assembly for approval to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences. The move, expected to contain provisions for posthumous pardons as well as pardons for living men, will bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales. Ms. Sugden said that arrangements would be brought in "as soon as possible to ensure that there is equal treatment for gay and bisexual men here as for their counterparts in England and Wales."

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second behind Faith Kipyegon in 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60. Muir now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from June 24 to 26. Muir recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
Some pictures from the 26 beaches in Scotland that are ranked as "most excellent" for water quality are provided.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC said suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Mr. Litvinenko, and the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot. Mr. Litvinenko was poisoned by a fatal dose of polonium-210 during a meeting with the two suspects, who deny any wrongdoing. Horwell stated the only credible explanation was Russian state involvement in Mr. Litvinenko's murder, though he stressed this did not mean Russian President Vladimir Putin was involved. He also said the suspects left a "trail of polonium" and had "no credible answer" to the scientific evidence.

Steve Smith, 26, will captain the Twenty20 team and the one-day side, with David Warner, 28, named as vice-captain. Smith had already captained the side in three Tests against India last summer. National selector Rod Marsh said that when Michael Clarke made his decision to retire, it was a straightforward decision to nominate Smith as his successor. Warner has earned the vice-captain's role despite a history of disciplinary problems.

Mr. Farron, who beat Norman Lamb to the leadership, stated he was "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and that defending equal marriage would be "at the top of my agenda", including extending marital rights of transgender people. He refused to answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin. Mr. Farron voted against the Equality Bill in 2007, citing concerns about "protection of individual liberties". He stated, "I am absolutely in favour of equal access under law for all people whatever their sexuality."

In 2015, Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare will now use the plant for pharmaceutical production, hoping to rehire many ex-Sanofi staff. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries worldwide. Councillor Nick Forbes stated the investment strengthens the area's reputation as a home for the science and healthcare sector, bringing skilled jobs and boosting the local economy.

Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, and Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn said the departures were indicative of the council's inability to hold on to senior staff. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their "dedication and professionalism".

English rider Guy Martin clarified his position on Facebook, stating he has no plans to do anymore road racing on the Hondas this year. Martin did not race at the North West 200 and will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix. He said to the team the bike won't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix and they decided to withdraw him from the event. He wants to race classics and oddball stuff.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP, which also lost the presidential poll, won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east, and lost key northern states. The APC retained power in Lagos state, and the Independent National Electoral Commission (Inec) reported 66 violent incidents at polling stations.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, accuses Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices. Mighty's report says that these practices may contribute to the haze caused by fires in Indonesia. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers. Olam chief executive Sunny Verghese stated that the firm had a "very vigorous sourcing policy" with zero tolerance for burning. Temasek has dismissed the allegations, stating that they "fully support no-burn policies for land clearance." The report also highlights concerns in Gabon, where Olam reportedly "bulldozes rainforests to establish monoculture palm oil plantations." Olam responded that its private-public partnerships in the country strove to be both responsible and transparent.
The restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law was introduced allowing dogs to eat at restaurants, as long as they were outdoors.
Forward Fernando Forestieri (knee) is a doubt, and David Nugent (groin) could return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube because Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. A Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) official confirmed that internet service providers had been directed to open access to YouTube. Pakistan's ministry of information technology stated that the PTA can make requests to Google to block access to offending material, and Google/YouTube will restrict access to the material for users within Pakistan. A YouTube spokeswoman clarified that government requests for content removal would not automatically be granted and may be restricted after a thorough review.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, as is Gianni Infantino, one of the five presidential candidates. Musa Bility, LFA boss, stated that he would go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala did not withdraw by Thursday. In 2015, Scala excused himself from the elections as he shared nationality with a candidate, Sepp Blatter. Fifa spokesman Andreas Bantel says "the fact that a member of the ad-hoc electoral committee has the same nationality as a candidate does not result in a conflict of interest." The election will take place in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at work at Harford Attachments on Monday shortly after 09:00 BST. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. Evidence suggests there was a flashover explosion, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and some sort of ignition. The Health and Safety Executive said its inspectors and electrical safety experts would be gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against Caf, but apologized and will participate. Morocco was able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on its participation and reduced a fine from $1m to $50,000. Equatorial Guinea stepped in to stage the 2015 finals. Tunisia's 2017 participation seemed in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Following last week's draw in Cairo, Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A while Morocco will Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome in Group F.

Chelsea won 3-1 at Etihad Stadium. Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for his second dismissal for violent conduct this season, following a high and late challenge on Chelsea defender David Luiz. Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban for clashing with Fabregas. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

A pilot program in Cwm Cynon and Neath is focusing on patients whose family doctors suspect have cancer but do not show any urgent signs or symptoms. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms in the Cwm Taf area receive a diagnosis. A similar clinic will be established in Neath Port Talbot Hospital. If the six-month Cwm Cynon pilot scheme is successful, the rest of the area's health boards will offer the same service in the following months.

England won at Old Trafford to level the series, with Joe Root named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance. Coach Trevor Bayliss said Root did "exactly what he said he was going to do." Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq said, "We are short of confidence and shot selection really cost us."

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand. Forwards coach McBryde assumes head coach responsibilities for the third time after leading Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde said it is an exciting opportunity to lead the team. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team.

Hull City secured a 2-1 victory over Southampton, ending a six-game losing streak, despite remaining in the bottom three. Robert Snodgrass, returning from injury, scored and assisted Michael Dawson in a two-minute span in the second half. This occurred after Charlie Austin's early penalty for Southampton. Hull's David Marshall made several key saves, and Sam Clucas made a crucial goalline clearance. Hull lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to injuries in the first half.
Quotes provided after the match include:
Hull City boss Mike Phelan: Praised players and highlighted individual performances and mentioned the international break comes at a good time due to injuries.
Southampton manager Claude Puel: Cited a lack of concentration and rhythm and stated it was a learning experience for future games.

The crash happened at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist killed in the collision lived locally. The tractor driver was not injured. Lincolnshire Police has appealed for witnesses to the collision to come forward. The B1191 was closed in both directions.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev said the move was illegal and urged protesters to gather in Skopje. EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn said Ivanov's actions were not in line with his understanding of the rule of law and put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The crisis was sparked by recordings that appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Saturday's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea wants to appoint their new boss as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis believes the current Swansea squad is good enough to stay up, and he reminds every new signing of how far the club has come.

The Daggers needed a victory to keep their survival hopes alive, but Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner to relegate Dagenham. Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona scored for Dagenham after Jay Simpson put the O's in a 2-0 lead. Dagenham now returns to the National League under John Still, the same manager who took the club from the Conference to League One. Still is committed to helping the Daggers gain promotion from the National League next season. Victory leaves Orient two points adrift of the play-off spots. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler stated that the team needs to win games to get into the play-offs.

The 36-year-old former Reds captain will return to his former club as a youth coach in February. He retired as a player in November after a 19-year career. Klopp said he had a good long chat with the ex-England skipper, and that Gerrard wants to be a manager in the future. Gerrard is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.

McManus scored the opening goal, followed by a second goal from Ross Forbes, giving Morton a double lead. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa, but McManus scored again, followed by Denny Johnstone, securing a win for the hosts.

Ofsted found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three now-closed locations in Birmingham. Eighteen unregulated schools have been visited as part of an investigation, and owners of the three closed locations are being investigated for running an illegal school, which could result in a jail term of up to 51 weeks. The government has provided funding for six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the education secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools. The government consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, is preparing to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes said the Scottish Borders has the potential to become a "region of distilling excellence." The gin takes its name from Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure who reputedly fought to avenge the death of her lover at the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died at Swithens Farm after Gary Green, 51, reversed a tractor into him. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. He was jailed for 16 months and two weeks and prosecuted under health and safety legislation. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, said her family had been "changed forever." HSE inspector Julian Franklin described Green's behavior as "reckless".

Luis Suarez, 27, is now allowed to train and play in friendly matches. He will join Barcelona's first team's training session on Friday, with a public presentation on Monday at Camp Nou. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) ruling prevents him from playing "organised" matches but allows him to participate in all "football-related activities". He will still serve eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games, and his competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be on October 26. In addition to training and playing in friendlies, Suarez can attend matches and participate in promotional activities.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna beat Lithuanian Vytautas Kirkliauskas, who was carrying his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. Competitors must tackle a 380-metre course, including hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols. The race saw all combinations of competitors, and you don't need to be married to take part. Richard Blake-Smith and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The paper system for car tax discs will be replaced with an electronic system in October 2014, allowing people to pay by monthly direct debit. Transport Minister Stephen Hammond said job roles would change, and reductions in the number of people needed would be managed through redeployment to other growth areas. Swansea East AM Mike Hedges welcomed the minister's assurances, stating it would comfort many concerned DVLA employees.

The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University. Mr. Szijjarto stated the EU should not interfere with "domestic issues." Poland has said it would veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. Human rights groups say draft legislation on NGOs expected to go before parliament soon would stigmatize them as "foreign-backed" organizations.

Emma Watson will play Belle, and Dan Stevens will play the Beast. Luke Evans will play Gaston, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. The star will play Mrs. Potts. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May. The film will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a columnist for the Sunday Times, passed away. He had been diagnosed with cancer and was undergoing chemotherapy. Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens described Gill as "a giant among journalists" and "the heart and soul" of the paper, which he joined in 1993. Gill's final column, discussing his diagnosis, will appear in tomorrow's Sunday Times. Many journalists and writers have paid tribute to him. Gill's articles were popular but often caused controversy, leading to outrage and censure.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator, reportedly hit with a bottle and kicked in the face. He spent about 10 days in a coma due to a brain injury. The swastika, a traditional symbol in Mongolia, was present on Sukhbaatar's clothing. The Russian embassy stated it was investigating reports of the assault, calling them "distorted." A Russian diplomatic officer is a suspect in the case, but was not detained.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday in opposition to the airport's expansion plans. They have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome and will appear in court on August 19. The protest took place on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. The Metropolitan Police said security at the airport would be reviewed.

Nick Selman scored a century (101 off 144 balls) for Glamorgan, with Aneurin Donald contributing 36 off 30 balls. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured regular wickets fell. Glamorgan's Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten secured a bonus point. Michael Hogan leads Glamorgan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph. Nick Selman and Matt Taylor commented on the match to the BBC.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. He was remanded in custody pending sentencing. Hughes made threats on two occasions while drunk, stating he planned to make a false report to the police so officers would come to the scene, and he would then shoot them. He had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009.

Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes (90) sharing a stand of 130. Yorkshire was all out for 236, with Tim Bresnan making 68. Stuart Meaker had a three-wicket burst in nine balls. Surrey skipper Gareth Batty stated that Davies and Foakes' partnership blew the game wide open. Yorkshire captain Alex Lees said that the team was gutted and that they thought it was a reachable target.

A 56ft converted trawler was 6 miles west of South Stack when the crew radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST. A pump on board the boat was unable to cope with the water coming in. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir's veterinary medicine studies will prevent her from participating in next year's event on Australia's Gold Coast, as her exams are in May and the Commonwealths are in April. Muir, a middle-distance runner, finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. She expressed that she is gutted to miss the Commonwealths, but her degree is very important to her. Muir says the World Indoor Championships in March are "potentially a target". After Sunday's race, she stated she was really happy and pleased with how she ran.

In a BBC Sport column, Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's challenges, noting they are "miles away" from another title challenge and must improve to secure a top-four spot. He attributes part of Liverpool's problem to overachieving last season and criticizes Rodgers' transfer market decisions, particularly up front, with available strikers Balotelli, Lambert, and Borini deemed "not good enough." Savage highlights a drop in goal-scoring and set-piece effectiveness, coupled with ongoing defensive issues. He suggests a lineup change, dropping Lovren for Toure. He emphasizes the need for improvement against Chelsea, who are on "a different planet." Savage also addresses Steven Gerrard's future, asserting he is not finished and can remain competitive, despite the mental and physical challenges of aging.

A Â£45m facility will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock. It will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council will ask the McIlvanney family for permission to name the campus in honor of the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. The novelist died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near the swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to a sea mine spotted on Monday, thought to be from the 1940s or 1950s. Residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors and open windows. Exclusion zones were in place on the river and at sea. Ferry services experienced some disruption. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community. Due to the mine's deterioration, the amount of explosive material it contained was unknown. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience.

A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, which is £2m less than the record amount allocated for the Rio Games. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals, and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Badminton is the only sport that earned a podium place in the summer to have its funding removed. UK Sport says investment in the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed, and funding will be determined "following further exploration of medal potential".

In Bournemouth's East Cliff, three Victorian hotels (Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View) will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (a nine-storey and a seven-storey building) with 122 apartments. Despite objections from English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society, councillors voted seven to three in favor of the project, citing the need to boost tourism and improve living conditions for older people. The council received 246 letters supporting the plans, while 49 residents objected.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was killed by Jake Vallely, 24, in Brecon while off-duty. Vallely was boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching and beating Pte Boyd, then dragging his body away. Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter. Vallely will be sentenced on December 8. A family tribute described Pte Boyd as loving, caring, and loyal, and stated that Vallely created "a void in our family that will never be filled."

Andrew Travers left the authority by "mutual agreement" after an error caused voters to be turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough. An independent investigation has been launched, and the council's review will conclude by the end of May with findings presented publicly to the General Functions Committee. John Hooton will take over temporarily as Deputy chief executive. Mr. Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the problems.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored a free-kick, and Sean Newton produced an equalizing set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning header for Gateshead. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby said that beating Wrexham shows that they have a decent side. Wrexham manager Gary Mills stated it was disappointing and that the team was too open at times in the second half.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway is ranked as the best country, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project aims to deliver global broadband links from orbit, connecting every school. It will initially consist of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000. This requires a shift in satellite manufacturing towards high volume and low cost, similar to car and plane factories, producing three units per shift at under a million dollars each. Airbus and OneWeb have established assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and Florida. The project involves a significant launch campaign, using over 20 Soyuz vehicles to deploy satellites. There are plans for nearly 300 satellites by the end of 2020 or the start of 2021, over 600 about a year later, and over 800 by the mid-2020s. OneWeb has secured $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking loans for full roll-out. The company is registered in the UK Channel Islands and is working with the UK Space Agency on licensing. Debris mitigation is a key concern, with a commitment to de-orbit old spacecraft within two years.

Mr. Swinney stated that the UK government's recent spending review put "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland. The Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. A UK government spokesman said the Scottish government would have £390m more in spending available next year. Labour’s public services spokeswoman Jackie Baillie said that John Swinney needed to back up his anti-austerity rhetoric with real action.

For many people with severe disabilities, their families, and carers, finding suitable toilet facilities is a significant challenge. Standard accessible toilets are insufficient for those needing additional support, such as carers or hoists. Campaigners, like Lorna Fillingham, advocate for compulsory Changing Places toilets in larger buildings, which offer enhanced facilities. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but they are different from standard disabled toilets due to extra features and more space. Changing Places specifications have been included in the Building Standards guidelines since 2009 as a recommendation, but campaigners want them to be compulsory for newly built larger complexes. Businesses in existing buildings face logistical and financial challenges in installing these larger toilets. Arsenal Football Club's installation of a Changing Places toilet has received positive feedback, highlighting the importance of accessibility for all customers.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations made a formal complaint to the European Commission accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. The SEIU and European unions support the complaint. McDonald's stated they share risks and rewards with licensees. The European Commission will study the submission and can launch an investigation. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh began after 13-year-old Joshua Martin was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff, started the hashtag, which has gone viral. A mystery donor paid for a billboard featuring the hashtag to be erected at Holywood playing fields. Josh's classmates have also been using the hashtag to support him.

Brecon Barracks is closing in a shake-up of UK military buildings and resettling of regiments. MP Chris Davies condemned the closure and launched a petition against the decision. The closure will not affect jobs of the 85 civilian staff and 90 military. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon said the reorganisation in Wales would see a specialist light infantry centre created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. Cawdor Barracks, Pembrokeshire will shut in 2024, while a storage depot at Sennybridge will go in 2025. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith said closing bases would affect the livelihoods of many people.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report that looks at the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry. The report states that the industry might be a low priority for the government, and it "must not be marginalised in the wider Brexit negotiations." The report also suggests that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal and points to the fact that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed the US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data on a massive scale. The US government confirmed requesting millions of phone records from Verizon. Prism enabled "backdoor" access to servers of nine major technology companies, including Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube, and Apple, though all companies denied involvement. NSA Director Keith Alexander stated that eavesdropping operations have helped keep Americans secure. US President Barack Obama defended surveillance tactics, stating, "You can't have 100% security and also then have 100% privacy and zero inconvenience." User data is often stored in different countries than the users themselves, with the US Patriot Act of 2001 giving American authorities new powers over European data. The EU Justice Commission said it was "concerned" about the consequences of Prism for EU citizens.

OpenAI aims to advance digital intelligence in a way that is most likely to benefit humanity, without being constrained by financial obligations. Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services are among the backers of the venture. The venture expects its research to focus on a "positive human impact," and it will spend only a tiny fraction of the $1bn pledged in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26. He has received thousands of Facebook requests, but the site limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. L/Bdr Parkinson's mother, Diane, said the responses had "been phenomenal" and that Ben was "buoyed up" by the support. A total of 8,000 people will carry the flame during its 8,000 mile, 70-day journey to the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in London on July 27.

In 2011, the poverty rate was 15%, meaning 46.2 million Americans were in poverty. Real median income of households dropped by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6%, and the percentage of Americans lacking health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%. In 2010, poverty in the US reached a record high of 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, 25, moved to the Red Rose in 2013, and his new deal ties him to the club until 2019. Buttler has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries. Ashley Giles, cricket director and head coach, said that Jos is one of the most talented cricketers in the game. Buttler will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until January 23 to register interest in the former Devonport-based ships, and viewings are set to take place in late February and March. A final decision on the sale is not expected until spring. The Disposal Services Authority wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler. Conservative MP Penny Mordaunt stated a preference for one to become a reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence will "consider all options" to ensure the "best financial return for the taxpayer".

Since 1987, racial and political tensions have caused instability and international isolation in Fiji. Coups in 1987 and 2000, and a military takeover in 2006, harmed the economy and Fiji's reputation. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 over its lack of progress towards democracy but was reinstated following elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with indigenous Fijians now making up a small majority. The economy relies on sugar and tourism, and there is mining, a strong service sector, and some light manufacturing. Fiji has persistent trade and budget deficits and is one of the world's largest per capita recipients of aid.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that "Syria is doing its best" to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline. He cited attacks on shipments as a reason for the delay. Al-Mekdad denied the use of barrel bombs in Aleppo and accused the US of supporting "terrorist elements." The Syrian government also denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) has acknowledged that the destruction process has been slowed by security concerns. Al-Mekdad stressed: "Syria is committed to all its agreements, with the OPCW and the UN Security Council. We shall implement on time all our obligations."

The winner of the 46th Booker Prize will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The shortlisted authors are Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, Richard Flanagan, and Mukherjee, with Mukherjee being the favorite to win. Each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves" is the best-selling novel of the shortlist. Last year, the Booker was won by New Zealand's Eleanor Catton for "The Luminaries".

The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether it should grant an appeal regarding a ban on a celebrity being named in the media in England and Wales. An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing. The man, referred to as PJS, wants to prevent the publication of an account of his alleged extra-marital activities, arguing he has a right to privacy. Court of Appeal judges initially ruled in his favor, but later lifted the ban, stating that details about the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost".

Fosse Park, opened in 1989, was bought in August for £345.5m. Plans are being prepared to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. The new owners met with Blaby District Council to clear up "potential planning questions". Crown Estates wants to address parking and congestion issues and improve the quality of common areas and facilities.

The film was due for release in Malaysia, but Disney said it was being held for a "review" of its content due to a "gay moment." The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the screening with "a minor edit concerning a gay moment in the film". The film was granted a "P13 parental guidance classification". LPF Chairman Datuk Abdul Hamid said that the date and location of the screening are not under the LPF's jurisdiction. Local cinema chains have been offering refunds for customers who have purchased tickets in advance.

Landlords who rent to more than three unrelated people need a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) license, which can cost £1,000, but many do not apply despite facing a fine of up to £20,000. Southampton City Council estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Mandatory licensing for HMOs nationally is for houses of three storeys or more, occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, licenses affect properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1 - introduced in 2013), Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2 - introduced in 2015). The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil hope to avoid a second election. Mr. Martin's party will facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government. Water charges are a sticking point, with a commission to consider the future of Irish Water proposed. Fianna Fáil wants the immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael sees a role for them. Following the election almost two months ago, no party was able to form a majority government.

The Sorrento was traveling to Valencia when a fire broke out and quickly got out of control. Passengers were evacuated onto lifeboats and rescued by another ship, the Puglia. At least three people have been injured and taken to the hospital by helicopter. The ship was about 27km (17 miles) from Mallorca when the fire broke out on one of the car decks, and the reason for the fire is unclear. The rescued passengers were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca. The ferry sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time (11:50 GMT).

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs had highlighted people claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offence. A record number of 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% actually voting, the highest turnout since 1997. Concerns over duplicate applications persist, with estimates ranging between 30% and 70% in different areas. The "dispersed and unconnected" nature of the 381 electoral registers in Britain means it is not possible to collectively cross-check entries, which would reduce the risk of double voting. Voting twice in a general election is an offence punishable by an unlimited fine.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, a former NFL player plagued by legal issues, was found to have killed himself early Wednesday. He was serving a 30-year term for assault and was recently placed in a cell alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate. A judge found enough evidence to try Phillips in the death of Damion Soward, 37.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, was promoted to lance corporal for "good behaviour" by Brigadier Andrew Williams. He is the 30th mascot ram, a tradition dating back to 1858. Officially classed as a soldier and joining the regiment in February 2014, Lance Corporal Derby XXX has an army number, gets paid rations, and takes holidays. He also switched on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory against Borussia Dortmund, advancing to the Europa League semi-finals. The match featured dramatic moments, including a late goal by Dejan Lovren. Liverpool overcame a 2-0 deficit, with Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, and Mamadou Sakho also scoring. The victory was attributed to a shift from "doubt to belief," a concept emphasized by Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp. The Europa League win also offers Liverpool a potential path back to the Champions League.

Mr. Davis said the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland up-to-date about negotiations and wanted to hold a monthly meeting to share analysis as part of a "two-way information flow." Mr. Russell said transparency about UK government plans was needed and that membership of the single market "is essential for the economic prosperity of Scotland". The UK government hopes the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered will be overruled on appeal to the Supreme Court next month, but the Scottish government will seek to oppose the UK government during the appeal.

Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr examines Daisy the sheep, a clone, for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is one of four sheep cloned from the same ewe as Dolly the sheep. Professor Kevin Sinclair and his team are studying 13 cloned sheep, including these four, to determine if they age normally and how healthy they are. This research addresses concerns about the cloning process and whether it leads to premature aging. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old and suffered from osteoarthritis. The study focuses on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis in the cloned sheep. The results will be published next week.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Dettori, won the Musidora, beating runner-up Vintage Folly. Shutter Speed will race at Chantilly next, while stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Oaks at Epsom. Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, won the Duke of York Stakes, with Magical Memory in second and Comicas third. Gosden will walk the course before deciding whether Cracksman runs in Thursday's Dante Stakes.

The currency initially slipped against the dollar and euro before recovering and then falling again, with the "volatility index" hitting levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226 and 0.6% against the euro at €1.2605, and it weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen. Investors have been spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote have fallen. Asian stock markets saw a significant fall, and the FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. Despite Braintree's losing run extending to three games, Cowley remained positive, stating, "What we've done so far has been nothing short of remarkable." He acknowledged the challenges faced by the part-time team, emphasizing their commitment to embracing and enjoying the journey. Barrow extended their unbeaten league run to nine games with the victory.

From April 2015, responsibility for planning decisions will shift to local councils, meaning elected politicians will make these decisions. Michael Corr, creative director of PLACE, sees this as a positive move, while the environmental group Friends of the Earth warns that a strict code of conduct will need to be enforced to ensure fairness. James Orr, Northern Ireland director for Friends of the Earth, is concerned about close relationships between developers and political parties and argues for transparency regarding political donations.

One-year-old Teenie, a cat, was shot three times with an airgun and had to have her leg amputated. The incident occurred in Winchburgh on March 14. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information to come forward. Scottish SPCA Ch Supt Mike Flynn highlighted the incident as a reason why the Scottish government should urgently implement the licensing of airguns. Last year, the Scottish government consulted on licensing air weapons, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan.

Benteke, a Belgium international, became Liverpool's second most expensive signing after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012 and scoring 49 goals in 101 games for Villa. Benteke said: "I came here to win trophies. I came here to reach some great goals with the team. "It was the right club for me because I had a good chat with the manager and I wanted to be part of his project." Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will do well at Anfield, and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is excited to see Benteke lead the Liverpool forward line.

A study commissioned by the charity Tablets for Schools looked at 671 state and independent schools. Tablets are being used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% of schools having an individual tablet device for every pupil. The number of tablet computers in schools is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. The study says there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices, but head teachers reported a positive impact and increased motivation for pupils. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers were particularly useful in helping boys and poorer pupils to learn to read. About two-thirds of students took a computer device or smartphone to bed with them, used for social media or watching videos.

The Museum of Liverpool is hosting an exhibition called "Growing Up in the City," featuring 25 photographs that capture children's lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History, selected the images from hundreds of options to depict both the positive and negative experiences of childhood. The exhibition runs until September 25.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has cancelled his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals. Striker Keating, 21, has joined Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson and was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Nicholson said, "Myles hasn't played a huge amount of games for a 27-year-old, but he is the stature, the voice, and is the leader-type I've been after," and he described Ruairi as "young, a little bit raw, but incredibly hungry to show what he's about."

The new legislation in Bolivia allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the needs of the country. It also sets harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The law was signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, and the government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty in Bolivia. The ILO is studying the legislation to decide whether it breaches international regulations on child labour.

Rosie O'Donnell, 50, experienced a heart attack known as the "widow maker". After experiencing symptoms such as chest aches, nausea, and feverishness, she looked up "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, and later saw a cardiologist who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. O'Donnell did not call emergency services but urged her readers to "Know the symptoms ladies, listen to the voice inside, the one we all so easily ignore, call 911."

Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was stabbed at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, after a scuffle in an alleyway at about 00:30 GMT and was pronounced dead about an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, along with two boys aged 15 and 16 who were bailed until mid-December. A 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

A team from Wales visited Aarhus, Denmark, to study their new approach to diagnosing cancer cases, especially those that are not initially obvious. Denmark's cancer survival statistics were poor compared to other European countries due to long waiting times for diagnosis. They introduced a three-route model: fast-track diagnosis for patients with "alarm" symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with vague symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms unlikely to be cancer. This has led to better organization of patient diagnosis and improved survival rates.

On March 31, 2014, Powys won the competitive bidding process to deliver the service in place of the OFT and will receive £170,000 a year to carry out the work. It will be able to issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. People complaining about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will prosecute offenders if necessary, but will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached.

NHS Employers has approved a plan for healthcare staff to take on extra tasks with more training, following a Nuffield Trust review. The review highlighted examples of nurses already filling in for doctors and pharmacists. Author Candace Imison said there were "huge opportunities" in reshaping the workforce, and NHS Employers chief executive Danny Mortimer said the challenge was to take forward the learning and recommendations in the report. However, British Medical Association leader Dr. Mark Porter and Unison head of health Christina McAnea expressed concerns about this being done at the expense of quality training and as a quick fix for staff shortages.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath after a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, but it caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services. Investigations are underway into how the collision happened. James Freeman, managing director, said that they were hoping to have a full service running in time for the evening commute.

NRW estimated the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed NRW's figures, claiming they had no "clear scientific basis" and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's computer modelling estimated a "worst case scenario" of 2% of all fish species being killed. NRW stated it strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism and has confidence in its evidence and methodology.

Arlene Foster, Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister, announced the development of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). It will provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities and play a pivotal role for both government and private sector organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill stated the agri-food sector is key in delivering export-led economic growth and that there was "a need for better coordination of current marketing activities."

The Woodland Trust is organizing a project to plant thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, as one of four new woods being created across the UK. The four-year project aims to plant "millions" of native UK trees to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. In Brackfield Wood, 40,000 trees will be planted in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The charity is providing saplings for the public to plant, advising volunteers to wear appropriate footwear. Limited parking is available at Brackfield Wood, about seven miles outside Derry city.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award. Judge Alison Graham described the book as "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story". The book, *Someone Else's Skin,* is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor. Paretsky set up Sisters In Crime, an organization to support female crime writers around the world.

Mitch Santner, 24, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016. Steve Rhodes, director of cricket, said losing Santner was a blow to their hopes of qualifying. Santner will rejoin the Rapids following June's ICC Trophy in England. He hopes to make an impact with bat and ball. In August, Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats of the game.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008. Coroner Dr. Elizabeth Earland recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that the car had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. Ms. Ziuzina, Pring's wife, tried to claim his assets within days of his death. Pring's family believes he was killed in a staged hit-and-run accident and that Ms. Ziuzina was involved in his death to inherit his money and property. Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry, which is still active "but not actively pursued".

Charlie, of Merseyside, needs to fly back to Seattle, America, for experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after the last transplant failed. An anonymous donor paid for the treatment. Charlie's parents said they received confirmation via an email from the hospital on Wednesday saying someone had offered to foot the bill for them. The treatment will start as soon as possible, and Mr. Fearns expects to find out the date next week.

Apple's iCloud security has been updated to include two-step verification, which requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via the Find My iPhone app. This prevents unauthorized access to iCloud, iTunes, iBooks, or App Store purchases. A 14-character recovery key is provided for account recovery. Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, previously used to bypass security, is no longer effective. Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication.

Dan Groves said the "finer points" of a deal that could see Wright buy 20% of Billericay are yet to be released. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright played non-league football for a succession of clubs. Multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin recently took over Billericay. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

Mr. Ashley has been asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse working practices. He has until March 21 to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The committee will be keeping the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage under review. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for comment but previously pledged to review worker rights, with oversight by Mr. Ashley.

The Russian-language report entitled Putin. War, completed by colleagues of a murdered opposition politician, presents a case accusing President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine. Russia denies sending troops, claiming any Russians serving there are "volunteers." However, the report argues that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in rebel victories. It includes evidence of volunteer soldiers directed by Russian generals, with salaries reaching $2,000–$3,000 a month. Russian spending on the conflict is estimated at 53bn roubles. The initial print run of the report was 2,000 copies, and the opposition seeks donations to extend it.

Craig Nelson, 34, also known as Craig Preston, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels. He died as a result of head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones expressed frustration with the UK government, stating he did not see the Article 50 letter before its publication and that the devolved administrations have been treated with a lack of respect. Alun Cairns disagreed with Jones, stating that the UK government needs to act in the interests of the whole of the UK. The UK government will consult on which powers should reside in Westminster and which should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, with the expectation of a significant increase in decision-making power for each devolved administration. The identity of the powers is currently unknown.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin said he was "appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community". Police were "carrying out duties" when attacked, according to a post on the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page. The post added: "We would also appeal to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing."

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The board stated it did not expect him to return. Mr. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, claimed many statements were false and that the company invaded Mr. Charney's privacy. The court filing includes evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts by Mr. Charney. The company stated that Mr. Charney violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. American Apparel was granted a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company and from trying to get board members removed.

Coverage of the game between the two teams will be on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The teams faced off earlier in the month, with Greece winning 92-64. The upcoming game is Britain's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017. After they play Greece, the team will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland.

When Steve Jobs unveiled the iPhone, it was not yet available to the public. The author was able to get his hands on the new iPhone by asking Apple’s marketing chief, Phil Schiller, and showed it on camera for his Ten O’Clock News piece. The author defended the coverage, saying some products merit coverage due to promising a step change in how we live. The smartphone has transformed technology, putting computers in over two billion people's hands. The iPhone has radically changed how we think about photography and other activities we can do on the move. Other firms like Amazon and Google are taking us forward with innovative products, but the mobile connected era began on that January morning in San Francisco.

Tests confirmed that cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray ingested a toxic substance. Seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday after consuming antifreeze, and three other cats in the area have died in the last seven days, with another dying two weeks ago. An RSPCA spokesman said it was unclear whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock is appealing for everyone in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely.

Even though the Syriza government is poised to agree and implement more austerity and liberalization measures, there are no demonstrations on the streets of Athens. Athens airport expects 25 million arrivals this year, up from 21 million. Greece is suffering from a vicious economic squeeze, which will further impoverish Greek people, and the new bailout will only hold if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead. For the bailout deal to lead to genuine recovery, Brussels and Berlin will need to avoid triumphalism and manifest debt forgiveness.

Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell from 1990–1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, will return to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes. Dame Barbara announced her character would be killed off after revealing that her cancer had returned. Grant Mitchell will be reunited with his mother and brother. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins said that having the Mitchell brothers come face to face again is an opportunity to show Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their very best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon fatally attacked Alice Ruggles after stalking her. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon when the police informed them of Alice's death. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice and dismissing her sister Emma's concerns. Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Alice's parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of the dangers of stalking.

EDF, a French firm, approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project, with one-third of the cost provided by Chinese investors. Despite this, Business Secretary Greg Clark stated the government will "consider carefully" before backing it, leading to a further review of the project. Critics have warned of environmental damage, potential escalating costs, and concerns about foreign governments building the plant. EDF chief executive Vincent de Rivaz has cancelled a trip to Hinkley Point. Key project milestones include the government proposing nuclear as part of the future energy mix in 2006, construction approval in 2013, an agreement to pay £92.50 per megawatt-hour in 2013, an investment agreement with China General Nuclear Power Corporation in 2015, and EDF's board approving the final investment decision in 2016, followed by the UK Government postponing a final decision.

The updated online divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person with whom the spouse committed adultery, though it is not required. Family lawyers express concern that naming a third party adds conflict and complexity. The Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name people. If the person is named, they become part of the court case. In 2015, there were just over 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales, with adultery cited in 12,148 cases and "unreasonable behaviour" in 46,815 cases.

Confor warns that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be re-planted to meet needs. Ministers are encouraging commercial forestry organisations to invest in woodland creation. The Welsh government wants a balance between the environmental, the economic, and the social in how forestry is developed, pointing to its Glastir scheme, which encourages farmers and other landowners to plant woodland. Martin Bishop of Confor believes the emphasis on environmental aspects is seen as "sexier" than commercial forestry.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency crews were called to the scene on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at about 16:40. The boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital, in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys, which were vessels that travelled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II. The Foreign Office initially did not allow Russia to honour the veterans, but made an exception last year. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, and more than 3,000 men died during the maritime campaign. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their work and said too many were let off if they did not attend. Anything from 40 to 300 hours of unpaid work may be given for offences like shoplifting, theft, drug offences, or criminal damage. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement. The chief inspector of probation, Paul Wilson, said it appeared in most cases that unpaid work was viewed simply as a punishment, which was a “wasted opportunity”. A Ministry of Justice spokesperson said it wanted "much more effective rehabilitation" and that they accept all recommendations and are taking action to implement them.

The comedian was called a "hypocrite" in a front-page headline for campaigning to help poorer people while living in a luxury home. He has been condemned as a hypocrite before. He believes in change, including personal change and sharing wealth, but argues that systemic change is also needed. He acknowledged doing "daft things" under the "capitalist fugue" but stated that this does not detract from the issues of economic disparity and ecological disaster.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the process of mapping the human genome. He founded Celera Genomics in 1998 and published their results alongside a public project in 2001. He later focused on creating a synthetic life form, Synthia, at the J. Craig Venter Institute, established in 2006. His work has faced criticism, but undeniably sped up the entire process of mapping the human genome. Dr. Venter also conducted a genetic treasure hunt, collecting life forms from the ocean to sequence their genomes. He believes synthetic microbes could potentially create a new industrial revolution.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents said their children asked for foods eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. About four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. More children in Scotland eat school lunches—about 46%. The survey was conducted online between February 26 and March 5 among a panel of parents who had at least one child in school aged 4–17 years old.

Morata, 23, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real. His move to Italy included an option for Real to buy him back for up to 30m euros (£23m). He scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He appeared in back-to-back Champions League finals. The 6ft 3in striker came through the ranks at Real, making his first team debut at 18, and scored 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson rejoined Forest in August 2013 for £2.5m, but has been without a team since being released in May. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground. He has also previously had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant, is exiting the US market by disposing of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. Tesco will loan the new business around £80 million, and the remaining 50 stores not transferred to Yucaipa will be closed. The disposal will cost Tesco £150 million.

He initially experienced racial abuse but overcame it. After briefly considering representing France, he is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. You can find out how to get into martial arts in our special guide.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, ice fields around Mont Blanc and surrounding mountains covered about 375 sq km. By the late 2000s, this area had fallen to about 275 sq km, representing an average loss of about 26% over the last 40 years. The retreat is not uniform, with the greatest losses in the southern sectors. The northern region includes the biggest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, which is just over 30 sq km, a shade smaller than its 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. Iceland is ranked number 20 in the world, one place above the Scots, and is also unbeaten with four wins from four. The outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September are likely to decide who tops the group. The best six of the eight group runners-up will qualify automatically for next summer's finals in the Netherlands. Evans recently celebrated winning the women's Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern.

Stuart Campbell was arrested on Friday following a complaint from a woman alleging online harassment over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail, stated the allegations concerned some tweets, none of which were threatening. A Metropolitan Police spokesman confirmed that police are investigating an allegation of online harassment. Campbell has been bailed until mid-September, pending further inquiries.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) suggests replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" to rebrand the resort as a progressive holiday destination. Dawn Carr of Peta said that the Jolly Fisherman "evokes images of cruelty to animals." The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, said that while all suggestions were welcome, he did not think there would be much support for replacing the mascot.

Scotland defeated Georgia with a final score of 38-11, highlighted by Stuart Hogg's two tries. Vasil Lobzhanidze scored the opening try for Georgia, but Scotland quickly took the lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Hogg. Hamish Watson extended the lead after half-time, while Lobzhanidze scored a second try for Georgia. Hogg then finished off a counter-attack for Scotland's sixth try. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's first-half performance and game management.

Widnes had a 14-6 half-time lead with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, with Paddy Flynn responding for Cas. Despite three Cas tries in four minutes from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick score, Widnes held on for a 38-12 victory. Widnes moved above Wakefield into seventh, while Castleford remain in sixth. The referee for the match was J Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from the US facility in Cuba after a US review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat." He had been held at the facility since 2002. His release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148. He is the first inmate to be freed since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, and up to 400 people took part in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was in 1916. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war.

Clarkson, 30, joined Premiership Well in July and might make his St Mirren debut against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season. Clarkson has been capped twice for Scotland in 2008 and has made almost 400 senior appearances at the club level. St Mirren is eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa.

Ranjit Boparan purchased the turkey firm on Tuesday. Unite regional officer Steve Harley said they were given guarantees that all current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and its members presently have an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover, which Boparan Private Office confirmed. Harley stated that the new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business by greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing the present spare capacity to process chicken and not just turkeys.
