Council leader Dave Stewart said the Cowes crossing would be free until July 2 "in recognition of the problems" and to allow feedback. He said the council had ordered a review of the project by auditors and that it had been a "frustrating and disappointing start" to the ferry. Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation for local businesses was up for discussion, and that there were electrical problems that the company has rectified. He also said groundings were an issue with seamanship, which had been resolved.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report that looks at the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry. The report states that the industry might be a low priority for the government, as UK fishing only produces a half of one percent of GDP and employs just 12,000 fishers. The report also suggests Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters in return for continued rights to sell fish to the European market with zero tariffs. Many in the fishing industry still argue that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats.

Timothy Geaney was removed from his profession's register following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing. He admitted to taking or permitting indecent images to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014. A GTC Scotland hearing was told that Geaney had "condoned and participated in an industry that violates and abuses children". The panel found him unfit to teach and removed him from the professional register, prohibiting him from applying to re-register for a period of two years.

A fire on March 2 at the Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited site in Duncan Street caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste and has now decided to revoke the environmental permit, meaning the company will no longer be able to operate from that site after August 7, subject to appeal. The fire service said the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The cause of the fire is still undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that "Syria is doing its best" to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline. He noted that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice. He insisted that Syria has "never bombarded places with civilians" and is committed to its agreements with the OPCW and UN Security Council. The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison. The US expressed concern that the UN-backed plan to destroy Syria's chemical weapons (about 1,300 tonnes) was falling behind schedule. Russia has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by March 1st, with a deadline for all weapons to be destroyed by the end of June.

England won at Old Trafford to level the series, with a score of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, marking their second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second, along with four catches and a wicket. Pakistan was bowled out for 198 and 234. Captain Misbah-ul-Haq said, "We are short of confidence and shot selection really cost us."

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira will gather experiences of residential care from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. As part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales, she will highlight good care and the impact of poor care. The review will examine factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, said his group supported the overall aims of the review.

Paul Sheerin, 39, has been a player-manager at Arbroath since 2010 and replaces Neil Cooper. Arbroath was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing the 2013-14 season bottom of League One. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser said boss Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after "a comprehensive process." Sheerin guided Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Saturday's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea wants to appoint their new boss as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis believes the current Swansea squad is good enough to stay up, and he reminds every new signing of how far the club has come.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the human genome mapping process. He later focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in an organism called Synthia. After being drafted into the Vietnam War, he decided to become a doctor. He sped up gene decoding and, in 1995, unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism, *Haemophilus influenzae*. In 1998, he formed Celera Genomics, completing the human genetic code in three years. In 2006, he formed the J. Craig Venter Institute, which spearheaded the creation of the world's first synthetic life form. He has also pursued projects such as sequencing genomes from microbes in the sea.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short, especially compared to those in Germany. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, with the majority at level three (equivalent to A-level) and lasting at least three years. The Department for Education says apprenticeships are being reformed to "drive up standards". The Association of Colleges said some existing apprenticeships were respected by industry and should be preserved.

The 37-year-old Briton won ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland. She is targeting further Paralympic success at next year's Games in Rio de Janeiro and can win a 17th title in Saturday's road race. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze) across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United's financial troubles, totaling £148,000 in debt to football creditors, led to their expulsion from the Football Conference despite multiple deadline extensions. The club's takeover by Tommy Agombar did not resolve the issues. Key dates include Hereford's final-day survival on April 26, a takeover by Tommy Agombar on June 3, and expulsion on June 10. Chester City, previously expelled in 2010, has been reinstated to the Conference Premier. The club faced debts of approximately £225,000 and still owes over £70,000 to clear the latest PAYE tax demand.

James Milner, 30, won 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) and a key figure in the early-music movement, died at his home in Cambridge after an illness lasting several months. He worked with many leading orchestras and made over 200 CDs with the AAM. Hogwood was also an artistic director, tutor, and professor at multiple universities. Tributes came from Christopher Purvis, Richard Egarr, Dame Emma Kirkby, and David Thomas. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held later.

A boy from Northern Ireland had to leave mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping. His parents requested a place for him at a special school, but in September, they were told that all the special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full. An extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school, and the boy will hopefully start there in the next few weeks. The Education Authority is reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure that places are available close to where the children reside.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, and a vote on the takeover will occur on May 9. County has a lease to use Rodney Parade until 2023 and expects it to be honored. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey said County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements, and the WRU is aware of that. County can clinch survival this weekend if they win and Hartlepool loses. Relegation to the National League would be a "massive" blow to the fans and the city of Newport.

Over the past 18 months, a virus in the country resulted in nearly 4,000 deaths. The passage details a personal account of experiences during the civil war, which concluded in 2002, and involvement in combating Ebola. Key actions in fighting Ebola included educating over 10,000 people about the reality of Ebola, supporting 11,000 people with food and supplies, and collaborating with other agencies to establish an Ebola treatment unit. One of the worst incidents witnessed involved a pregnant woman with suspected Ebola, which prompted the start of setting up an Ebola treatment clinic.

About 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs were at risk of being auctioned to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt. A public fundraising campaign raised the necessary funds, and the collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then be loaned to the Wedgwood Museum.

Dan Groves said the details of a deal for Wright to buy 20% of the club are yet to be released. The 30-year-old is reported to become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright played non-league football for several clubs. Billericay was recently taken over by Glenn Tamplin. At the start of March, the club signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool and Colchester United finished 1-1. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool after 12 minutes, and Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester from the resulting corner after Sam Slocombe denied Matthew Briggs. Tom Aldred missed a chance for Blackpool 15 minutes from time. Sean Murray of Colchester was shown a red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time, leaving Colchester with 10 men.

Fawley Waterside developers plan to make the disused Fawley power station chimney the centrepiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development, featuring a marina, housing, and restaurants. The power station closed in 2013 after more than 40 years in operation and was sold to the developers in 2016. Building could start in 2018.

In the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old Latham secured a bronze medal in the men's scratch, chasing down gold medalist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver medalist Lucass Liss of Germany. Elinor Barker won a silver medal in the women's scratch on Wednesday. In the men's team pursuit, GB was beaten to the bronze medal by Italy, and in the women's team pursuit, GB finished fifth in the heats. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell from 1990–1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, will return to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes. Dame Barbara’s character, Peggy, will be killed off in the spring due to cancer. Grant Mitchell will be reunited with his mother and brother, Phil, played by Steve McFadden.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as second-placed Spurs were defeated at Anfield. Mauricio Pochettino stated, "It is difficult to fight for the Premier League if you show that lack of desire to play for a win." He also said, "In the first 45 minutes you saw a team that is not ready to fight for the Premier League." Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy noted that Spurs' defensive performance was uncharacteristic, especially given their strong record.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP lost key northern states and Adamawa, but held on to Rivers State, winning eight governorships overall. The APC retained power in Lagos state. The election in Imo state was declared inconclusive, and the Taraba result is outstanding. The Independent National Electoral Commission (Inec) reported 66 violent incidents at polling stations.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22) will be able to use an app to trigger online information, including videos and band interviews, from items such as signs and posters. The app will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival. The message will be updated in the run-up to and during HebCelt, allowing people to instantly access information and interviews, buy tickets, and get a taste of the festival wherever they are.

Ofsted rated Park View and Nansen Primary as inadequate, and their funding agreements will be terminated. Golden Hillock School and Oldknow Academy were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher reported that parents tried to undermine her authority. The education minister, Lord Nash, expressed "deep concerns" about how Park View School was run. Park View School said they would challenge the Ofsted report. Lord Nash outlined actions for Oldknow Academy to take before July 4, including ending "less favourable" treatment of non-Muslims and ceasing segregation. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw said "a culture of fear and intimidation has taken grip" in Birmingham schools. Some parents have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test. Honey Rose, 35, an eye specialist, is accused of gross negligence manslaughter due to allegedly failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution alleges that Vinnie's death was preventable. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with a man between September 10, 2013, and September 17, 2014. He was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on December 25, 2014. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and assessed as posing "a moderate risk" of sexual re-offending.

Ireland made 165-5, with Stuart Thompson hitting 56 and Gary Wilson (41 no) and captain William Porterfield (39) adding runs. Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs to spare, with Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) helping them to their target. Amir Hamza (2-23) was the only bowler to take more than one wicket. William Porterfield stated that they could have added 15 more runs to get to 180. Boyd Rankin was out with a back problem but is expected to return for the five ODIs against Afghanistan on March 15.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Santos striker Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. Neymar will have cost the club £106.8m between the initial fee, signing-on fee, wages, agent fees, and tax payment. The club denies the existence of any tax-related crime in relation to the fiscal obligations arising from the signing of the player. FC Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to defend the club's reputation and good name. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK detectives traveled to Thailand to review the investigation and will now return to the UK to compile a report and update the families. Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21-year-old migrant workers from Myanmar, are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty. Post-mortem examinations found Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Miss Witheridge died from head wounds.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and will likely secure their place if they win against Iceland, who are also unbeaten with four wins. Forward Evans said that reaching the finals is everyone’s aim. Scotland is in a good position to reach next summer’s finals in the Netherlands. Evans believes that having more players in the world's top leagues benefits the national team.

Apple introduced a two-step verification process to prevent third-party software from infiltrating iCloud, requiring users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via the Find My iPhone app. This action was in response to the use of Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker in the recent hacks, which allowed unauthorized access to iCloud backups. Elcomsoft's owner, Vladimir Katalov, acknowledged that the changes guard against the technique he had used. Apple plans to encourage people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning for the May election. UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Tories spent £2,980,815, the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, Labour spent £1,027,339, and the Green Party spent £534,249. The SNP spent £267,372. All but Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign. The figures cover 23 January to 22 May.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has cancelled his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals. Striker Keating, 21, has joined the Gulls and was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson stated that Myles Anderson hasn't played many games for a 27-year-old, but he is the leader-type he's been after, and Ruairi Keating is young and hungry to show what he's about.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, stated that such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but did not display these symptoms on Saturday.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears after speeches by MSPs Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond, who are stepping down ahead of the election on May 5. Mr. Salmond repeated his belief that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse". Mr. McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also bowing out of Holyrood.

Emma Watson will play Belle, and Dan Stevens will play the Beast. Luke Evans will co-star as the villainous Gaston, and Josh Gad will play Gaston’s sidekick LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, the father of Belle. The star will play Mrs. Potts. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May. The film will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST to reveal its intentions regarding the 1989 stadium disaster where 96 football fans were fatally injured. Last year, new inquests concluded the fans had been unlawfully killed. In January, files of evidence relating to 23 suspects were referred to the CPS. Relatives have been invited to a private meeting in Warrington, where they will be informed of the decisions by Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over the wall. A former inmate said the jail was "notorious" for being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice said staff worked "extremely hard" to stop contraband from getting into prisons, and laws have been introduced to jail those who smuggle packages for up to two years. One resident near the prison witnessed packages being thrown over the wall "four times in two weeks."

Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, told Luton Crown Court he had been blinded by the setting sun when he struck Sylvia Blackburn, 72, with his VW Golf. Mrs. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now being treated in residential care. Mr. Wright denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr. Wright's eyes. The trial continues.

Muir will not be with the Scotland team at next year's event on Australia's Gold Coast because of her veterinary medicine studies. The middle-distance runner stated, "My exams aren't until May so Commonwealths being in April, it's just not going to work out unfortunately." Muir's time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships was her new outdoor personal best. Muir says the World Indoor Championships in March are "potentially a target".

Trevor Deely, 22, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a three-acre woodland site in Dublin began on Saturday morning and is expected to take a number of weeks. Earlier this year, a team of six detectives began a complete review of Mr. Deely's disappearance. Enhanced CCTV footage from the night he went missing shows Mr. Deely talking to a man dressed in black. Detectives believe he was the same man captured on CCTV following Mr. Deely a short time later. Gardaí said the man has not yet been identified and they renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Del Potro achieved a victory over the Swiss player, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3. Del Potro, ranked 165th, will face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next. Nick Kyrgios beat Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4 and will play Feliciano Lopez in the third round. Tomas Berdych beat Benjamin Becker 6-4, 6-1, 6-2, and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga defeated Juan Monaco 6-1, 6-4, 6-3.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations for complaints lodged against Caf, but they apologized. Morocco was able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on its participation. Equatorial Guinea stepped in to stage the 2015 finals. FTF vice-president Maher Snoussi stated that there would no longer be any problems between Tunisia and Caf. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The team has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. McLaren's slump started in 2013, when they lost their way on chassis design but still had the best engine. In 1988, with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, they won 15 of the 16 races. McLaren's last constructors' title was in 1998. In 2007, McLaren was kicked out of the constructors' championship and fined $100 million after being found guilty of illegally possessing Ferrari technical information. In 2009, after Hamilton and Dave Ryan were found to have misled the stewards, Ryan was sacked. McLaren's F1 history has been a cycle of triumph and decline. Ron Dennis took complete control and has held it ever since, in one role or another. Dennis insists it is only a matter of time before success will return.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven on October 6, 2014, at 06:00 BST for a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar, with receipts showing alcohol being served as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill was charged with two counts of allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours, and James Thomas faced one count of the same charge. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Ms. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and nine assists as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Klay Thompson scored 26 points for the Warriors. LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds, and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists for the Blazers. Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls beat Miami Heat 89-78. Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scored 14 points for the Bulls. Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for the Heat.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at Melwood. The players believed van Velzen was a competition winner, but he showcased his free-kick skills, impressing the players. Van Velzen said, "the whole experience was amazing," and he enjoyed pretending he wasn't good at free-kicks and seeing the players' faces when he shot.

A study of 676 breast cancer patients with mutated BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes showed that oophorectomy (ovary removal) significantly reduces the risk of death. The 20-year survival rate for the entire group was 77.4%. Oophorectomy was associated with a 62% drop in breast cancer death in women with a BRCA1 mutation, and a 65% reduction in death from all causes. For BRCA1 carriers who had their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis, there was a 73% reduction in death. Oophorectomy was particularly effective for survival in women with estrogen-receptor-negative breast cancer.

Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by Amtrak train No. 80, the Carolinian, on Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The train was heading north from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay did receive treatment. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing on its route.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked for the DEA for 27 years as an undercover operative after fleeing Colombia and the Medellin Cartel in the 1980s. He was promised US citizenship but is now living in the US illegally after retiring. Toro's information helped prosecute figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. He was given $5,000 by a former colleague for an operation after the DEA declined to help. Toro is currently seeking a green card or passport.

The US body that regulates internet addresses (ICANN) is looking to crack down on a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new '.sucks' domain name. ICANN sent a letter to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to see if the company's actions were illegal. Vox Populi began accepting registrations using '.sucks' on March 30. Names purchased include youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, bankofamerica.sucks, and yahoo.sucks. It has recommended charging $2,499 a year for the privilege, and most of the names have been sold by resellers for around $2,000 a year. Celebrities such as Kevin Spacey have reportedly paid to have their '.sucks' domains removed.

A baby boy's body, found in 1988, was exhumed, and DNA evidence led police to his mother. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she revealed the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy. She placed the baby in a pond in Weasenham St Peter. Police ruled out foul play, and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, now named Peter, was reburied. The case was solved using advances in DNA, which matched a family member on the national database.

Taxi driver Michael Young, 56, was ordered to compensate passenger Kristopher Hicks, 27, for severe brain injuries he sustained after jumping out of Young's moving taxi. Young mistakenly believed Hicks would not pay and unlawfully imprisoned him, driving him back to the rank. Hicks jumped from the vehicle while it was traveling at more than 20mph. Mr. Justice Edis ruled Hicks was entitled to damages, the exact amount yet to be decided, but around 50% of the family's request and an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Hicks now requires round-the-clock care due to his injuries, including epilepsy. Both sides were given permission to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the final amount Young must pay.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night due to several storms, with reported twisters near Goddard and in southwestern Kansas. CNN's severe weather expert Chad Myers noted that nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous. Missouri also experienced potential tornado activity near Potosi, with reports of wind damage and flooding. Additional storms are expected on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold believes he needs to "be the bull" and "dominate" Lyoto Machida in their upcoming middleweight clash. Rockhold, bidding for his fourth consecutive victory, plans to "cut him off" and "make him fight my fight." He respects Machida's fighting style but plans to dominate. Machida is confident he can upset Rockhold and earn himself a title shot by applying his style and technique. Both fighters are coming off victories.

A light general aviation aircraft in Fort Pierce, Florida, approached the Aero Acres residential airpark for landing without deploying its landing gear. The plane touched down, its propellers hitting the runway, but the pilot re-engaged the engines and took off again. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error, although mechanical fault can also cause it. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini admitted he is disappointed in Yaya Toure's performance this year, but will support him until the end of the season. Manchester City will listen to offers for Toure in the summer. Pellegrini faces questions over his own future, but goalkeeper Joe Hart said the players should take responsibility and that Pellegrini retained the backing of the dressing room. Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to City.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive living in the UK for over 20 years, will be allowed to stay after his 7-year sentence from an Italian court in 1999 was dropped. The case expired in October, and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn, although his conviction remains. Italian law dictates a sentence is extinguished after double the penalty time has passed. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) stated the case would still be heard by the Italian supreme court. Rancadore was initially arrested in 2013, and extradition proceedings were protracted, with a judge reversing his initial decision over concerns about Italian prison conditions. There was criticism of the time and money spent on the case. The CPS admitted to a mistake that may have contributed to the outcome.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the seven-runner lineup for the grade one Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. Mr Mole is bracketed with Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. Other runners include Somersby. McCoy shocked the racing world by announcing his intention to quit riding after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder and received a sentence of 44 years. Recently, Ritter saw the crime scene photos of her daughter's body and described the horror of seeing them.

Rory McIlroy aims to win the Masters, completing the career grand slam, a feat achieved by only five others. He believes his 2011 collapse at Augusta was crucial for his career. McIlroy sees the golf course as a "sanctuary" from external pressures. He has had one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances. McIlroy won his first major title by eight shots in the US Open two months after his collapse at Augusta.

- Four rainbows appeared in the New York area after a large amount of rain.
- In rural China, hiring exotic dancers at wakes is increasingly common, but the practice is now the focus of the country's crackdown on vice.
- An interviewer from the UK asked RDJ about his private life on Tuesday.
- The latest trend is lip plumping by sucking on a jar to look like Kylie Jenner.
- 102-year-old Alice Barker went back in time with help from some filmmakers.
- A prom-posal that referenced bombs was not accepted by one school.
- Ewan McGregor to play Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'.
- Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer.
- A pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."
- A military dad photobombed his son.

Alarming new figures have revealed that hundreds of children were admitted to hospitals last year after being born brain-damaged following exposure to alcohol in the womb. 272 youngsters disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England over the past 12 months. Research by the World Health Organisation suggests that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to exposure to alcohol. Other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy include problems with the liver, kidneys, and heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender, attempted to rob a store while wielding an axe but was stopped by the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, and his wife. The shopkeeper tackled McKerry, and his wife hit him with a baseball bat, disarming him. Police arrived and arrested McKerry. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years.

Four Royal Navy sailors (Joshua Finbow, 23, Craig Stoner, 24, Simon Radford, 31, and Darren Smalley, 35) have been charged with gang rape at a Canadian barracks. They were given bail conditions requiring them to surrender their passports, live at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax, and remain employed by the Royal Navy. They are forbidden to contact the victim and six witnesses, must stay in Nova Scotia, and cannot apply for new passports. The charges carry a potential sentence of up to 14 years in prison.

RJ Jackson, a four-year-old, has Netherton's syndrome, a rare skin condition that affects only 70 people worldwide, causing his skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly. His mother, Valerie Jackson, regularly applies creams to manage his condition. She has faced accusations of child abuse, including an incident where she was surrounded by armed police while shopping, due to a misunderstanding of RJ's condition. Netherton's syndrome is a congenital skin disease, a severe form of ichthyosis, with symptoms that include red, scaly skin, and potential hair, infection, and allergy problems. There is no cure, but symptoms can improve over time. Mrs. Jackson found support and information through a Facebook group dedicated to Netherton's syndrome.

The "Are you beach body ready?" Protein World advertisement featuring a bikini-clad model, Renee Somerfield, is being removed from the London Underground. Transport for London (TFL) stated the removal is because the three-week advertising period ended. The campaign sparked controversy, with over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition calling for its removal and over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) citing concerns about unhealthy body image promotion. Many posters were defaced. Protein World defended their campaign and engaged with critics on social media. Richard Staveley, Protein World's head of global marketing, stated that the campaign was meant to encourage people to be fitter. He also mentioned that the company had received threats, including a bomb threat. The ASA is assessing the complaints to determine further action.

Rail firms are planning fare hikes of up to 87 percent after the general election, despite party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western (FGW) to review its decision to almost double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds. From May 17, some customers will be forced to pay £62.40 instead of £33.30 for certain return trips, an 87% increase. Other price hikes include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton on London Midlands rising from £30 to £37. Virgin has said the vast majority of its price hikes affected "virgin trains-only fares," which are at least 20 percent cheaper than tickets offered by rival firms, and that its overall fare increase this year on the west coast is just 1.65 percent.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, was blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown by thugs. The incident occurred at his Oldham home when he confronted individuals throwing stones at his property. Despite emergency surgery, doctors couldn't save his eyesight. The attack occurred three weeks after his wedding, with no known motive, possibly a case of individuals "messing around". Police have launched an investigation.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a new one-year contract extension after returning from leg injuries sustained in a road accident. He missed the entire 2014 campaign and had to undergo an ankle operation. Poynton will be available for the start of the season and has committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's elite performance director, said that Tom has displayed exceptional character and worked tirelessly to prepare for his return.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually. He battled cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. Harley used a ninja turtle mask to feel stronger during radiotherapy. After undergoing intensive treatments, including chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, he was declared cancer-free. Harley's bravery led to him receiving a Cancer Research UK's Little Star Award and becoming the face of the charity's Kids and Teens campaign. Neuroblastoma is a cancer of specialized nerve cells, with symptoms varying based on the tumor's location and treatments including surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

According to Tim Sherwood, Jack Grealish must concentrate on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future. Sherwood wants Grealish to focus on forcing his way into the Villa first team. Grealish has to decide whether to play for the Republic of Ireland or England, and he is expected to choose between the two at the end of the season. Grealish's dad, Kevin, agreed that his son must concentrate on his club football first.

Landing fees for private jets vary dramatically at different airports, with some unexpected hubs charging the highest fees. The most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport charging £4,559 ($6,850). Other airports in the top 10 include Toronto Pearson International Airport, Darwin International Airport, Bristol Airport, Chūbu Centrair International Airport, Dublin Airport, La Guardia Airport, and Salzburg Airport. The busiest weekends for private jet companies are during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix. In 2013, there were 2.5 million private flights in the US and 705,000 in Europe.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dogs, Cooper and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. Cooper eats the ice cream in one bite, while Daisy takes a few licks. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, says Cooper always eats quickly. The video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched more than seven million times. Another video shows the duo visiting Starbucks for a `pup-uccino,' where Cooper demolishes the contents, which is merely a dollop of whip cream in a cup.

Gary Locke has been given the role of Kilmarnock manager on a permanent basis after signing a three-year deal. He joined the club as assistant boss to Allan Johnston last summer, but took control of the team when his ex-Tynecastle team-mate quit. Locke has lost just once in seven games since taking over. He shakes hands with chairman Jim Mann after signing a three-year deal at the club.

Jessica Kemp, a Florida mother, says Seminole County Elementary teachers threatened to remove her five-year-old autistic son from class because the Doterra essential oils he wears smell and are a distraction. She applies the liquid to his head and neck as it helps him keep calm and focused. Kemp received a letter from the local school board stating the oils had created a `problem' for staff and students. However, Lake County School District said they would not suspend Logan, saying it was a `health issue'. The family uses oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A fire at a beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons destroyed 90 condos on Wednesday at 3 pm. The fire was so intense that it melted paint off nearby buildings, and smoke could be seen from three miles away. Twelve fire teams were deployed but could not get inside the building. The cause of the fire is unknown, but there are claims it started near a parked car. The Sandpiper complex is open between May and November.

The Queen, 88, was seen riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She has always loved horses and has ridden since she was four. Although she has reduced her riding time due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian. The Queen breeds fell ponies, a breed that has been around since the Neolithic period and has been used for various purposes throughout history, including by the Romans and Vikings. Today, fell ponies remain a popular choice for riders.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels resulted in the death of Leon Yeaman, 55. Phillip Pama, 28, was charged with manslaughter after allegedly killing Yeaman with a single punch. Pama was granted conditional bail and ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to the local police station twice a week. The case is due to return to court on May 18.

Jose Mourinho prays every day and has strong faith in God, but never prays about football. He is a good family person and tries to separate his professional and family life. Mourinho was fined £25,000 for claiming there was a "campaign" against Chelsea after Cesc Fabregas was booked for diving.

On the April 1 edition of "The Price is Right," Bob Barker, who hosted the show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, returned to host the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven." Barker, 91, then turned hosting duties over to Drew Carey, who finished up.

Secret Service Agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 am on Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE in Washington D.C. He was charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. The agency revoked Baldwin's security clearance and put him on leave. Court records show Baldwin was to be arraigned Friday afternoon.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, took a risk to capture an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away at the city's safari park. He crept to within 10 feet of the lion before the sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, forcing him to retreat rapidly into his car. He said he wouldn't be able to do it again.

An unnamed woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn and was pronounced dead that evening. The woman had a distinctive heart tattoo with the name "Monique" on her right leg. Police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, built a two-bedroom, wood and steel home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK. The solar-powered home allows them to live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. The project took a year and a half and cost about $25,000. The home is powered mostly by solar panels, with a wood-fired stove, gas-powered hot water, and water from a nearby spring.

Researchers claim that children who share iPads in class do much better in early literacy tests than those who do not. Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads significantly outscored their peers who were in classes that had no iPads or in which each student had their own device. Shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher than students who used the device on their own and non-iPad users. Blackwell suggests collaborative learning around the technology made the difference.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "super pig," belongs to farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai City in Sichuan province, China. A video of the piglet walking has captured the hearts of thousands. The piglet is able to mix with its siblings, which were all born with four legs.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, tire changer Todd Phillips was injured when Francesco Dracone's car spun and clipped Phillips' leg on lap 25. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, received stitches, and was released. Dracone did not finish the race and wound up 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, by smashing her head into concrete, punching her, and shooting her. Security camera footage captured the incident. Severiano confessed, saying he was jealous of men looking at her. A neighbor reported hearing an argument before the gunshots, with Severiano accusing his wife of being a "slut." After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was apprehended by police after crashing it. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car.

Sarah Wilson, 41, a journalist and author, revealed in an interview that she came close to taking her own life due to anxiety and other issues, including mounting stress, her thyroid disease, and distant family. She felt isolated and couldn't see a way out. Ms. Wilson believes that depression and anxiety are linked and that anxiety is becoming the "new depression." She now accepts she is an "anxious person." Beyond Blue reports that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime. Contact information for Beyond Blue and Lifeline is provided.

Elena Curtin, of Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin was seven months pregnant at the time. When Curtin came home, she found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend shooting heroin while sitting on her toilet. When she asked her to leave and the woman refused, Curtin beat her with a crowbar. Prosecutors dropped the charge on Monday because Curtin was ‘completely justified in her outrage’. If she had gone to trial and been convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma the pit bull was filmed at home in California being fed treats. Her owner throws a broccoli spear into the mix, and she pulls a look of disgust, chomping on the vegetable and spitting it out on the floor. Other videos show Gemma enjoying sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The bank removed the hyperlink from its main website after realizing the mistake. A spokesman denied the bank had any associations with the external site and offered its apology to the public. HSBC stated, "a link to an external third-party website has been removed" and that "HSBC is not in any way associated with the external third-party website."

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 after his family's home caught fire, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus provided instructions to the dispatcher and soothed his sister during the 11-minute call. Prince George's County firefighters rescued them by entering the room through the home and breaking a window. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to Medstar Hospital.

Amazing pictures have emerged of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast. The images were taken in Jervis Bay, as the neon glow illuminated one of Australia's popular beaches. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a `beautiful supernatural scene' caused by millions of plankton omitting light. A similar display was shown in Sydney's Manly Beach back in August 2014. Iain Suthers, of the University of New South Wales, says the algae blossoms in the spring and the autumn.

New tests that pinpoint genetic markers in breast cancer tumors can determine their aggressiveness and risk of returning after surgery. Women can be told within days whether they have a high or low risk of the disease returning, with some tests accurately showing a risk as low as five percent. If the Endopredict test shows a low score, patients can opt not to have chemotherapy. Most of the tests are available only privately and cost about £2,500.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding or during leave. Between January 2006 and December 2013, ninety-nine servicewomen were flown back to the UK from Afghanistan due to pregnancy. A further 102 women were evacuated from Iraq. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was found on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The discovery coincided with a court approval to restart two nuclear reactors, a move unpopular among many Japanese. The drone was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing traces of cesium. The amount of cesium is not immediately harmful to humans. The government will work to prevent terrorism.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from China, takes his 84-year-old mother with him to work every day on the back of his motorbike because she suffers from Alzheimer's. He ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure she does not fall off. He decided to take his mother with him to work after his father passed away because there was no one else to look after her. He said his mother devoted her life to caring for her children, and now he feels like he has a duty to care for her in return.

A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with rising rates among women largely contributing to the increase. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers, and 18% were binge drinkers. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. Researchers analyzed data on about 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System.

UN officials warn that doctors are putting women and babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily. The procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary because it can lead to infections and even death. The WHO stated that caesarean sections are often performed without medical need, leading to short- and long-term health problems, significant complications, disability, or death.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She was discovered by owner Mark Conklin at his property in Edgartown. A construction worker reported seeing Filkins outside with items from the home, appearing to be having a yard sale or giving them away. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department and can contact them with information at 508-627-4343.

Bella Crooke's lost iPhone was turned in to Albury police station. Police officers posted a series of photos on Bella's Facebook page to track her down, as the phone was unlocked. The posts included selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the police station. Bella eventually reclaimed her phone, and the police officers recognized her from her Facebook page.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park, in eastern South Africa. The calf was flung into the air and dragged along the surface of the water. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the event. The mother tried to save the baby, but the calf died hours later from its injuries.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000, a fraction of the price of neighboring homes, due to having only three years left on the lease. This cost equates to £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, similar to the area's rental rate for a three-bedroom flat. The "unmodernised" maisonette boasts 1,990 sq/ft of space.  Extending the lease could increase the property's value to upwards of £6 million. A second, larger maisonette on Egerton Place is also for sale with a three-year lease for £595,000.

A computer outage affected registers at 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada, leading to free drinks being given away. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. Starbucks stated that the issue has been resolved and stores are expected to open for business as usual on Saturday. The outage occurred just after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorist training and radicalization of Muslims are occurring in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Detective Constable Gareth Jones stated that those involved participate in seemingly ordinary activities but have ulterior motives. He also emphasized the importance of community intelligence.

- An Omura's whale, a species feared to be extinct, was discovered on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia (WA) after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn.
- It is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia.
- Department of Parks and Wildlife staff identified the 5.68m juvenile female through DNA profiling.
- Environment Minister Albert Jacob said the find was "highly significant" because very little is known about the species, which was first described in scientific journals in 2003.
- The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possibly for public display.
- The species is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan.
- Omura's whales have a sleek body shape and several unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae.

According to Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, women shouldn't be president because their hormones might make them start an unnecessary war. Rios has taken flak for her views, but she is not the only one arguing that a woman’s hormones are a legitimate leadership concern. *Time* magazine declared Hillary Clinton the "perfect" age to be president because she is a postmenopausal woman who is "biologically primed" to lead. There is a bias against women in the workplace, and gender stereotypes need to be eradicated. Rios stated that if Clinton is elected, she is "moving to Canada" because "a female shouldn't be president."

Robert Hardy, an 89-year-old veteran actor known for roles such as Winston Churchill and in "All Creatures Great and Small," is auctioning off his antique collection due to downsizing. The collection includes over 200 items, such as a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow, paintings, furniture, and books, some dating back to the 17th century. The auction, featuring 238 lots, is set to take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire. Mr. Hardy expressed sadness at selling his collection, which reflects his interest in military history and classic literature.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their shared home. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead. Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for attempted suicide. Authorities have the murder weapon but will not confirm how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Anyone with information as to his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities at 407-656-3636.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations council bypassed the usual bidding process due to a perceived unique strategic opportunity to host the championships in the USA for the first time. IAAF President Lamine Diack stated that the decision was made to take advantage of a unique opportunity.

Leonie Granger, 25, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death. Granger used her looks to befriend Hassan, who was a "soft target," after spotting him flashing cash at a casino. She left his door unlocked so her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, 28, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, 29, could enter.  They tied up and kicked Hassan to death while ransacking his home for winnings. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and jailed for life with a minimum term of 36 years. All three were convicted of robbing Hassan and conspiracy to falsely imprison him.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas is noted for struggling in the second half of the season. His form has significantly dipped, and he was one of the worst players on the pitch in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland. Despite a strong start with 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, he has since added only one in five games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. Barcelona, his former club, noted a downward trend in his stats every season.

West Ham is discussing a deal for Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward who impressed coaches after training with the club. Beckford also has offers from clubs in Belgium. Season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289, and West Ham will have the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League.

Mike Lane, 40, was attacked by protesters and criticized the police's decision to drop the investigation as 'pathetic.' A video and evidence were given to Wiltshire police, but they stopped the investigation pending further information. Lane, who suffered injuries and memory loss, expressed his disappointment and loss of trust in the police. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings. A Wiltshire police spokesman stated the case was recorded as undetected, but will be re-opened should other evidence come to light.

Adam Gadahn, 36, also known as the "American mouthpiece of al Qaeda," was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, born in 1978 and also known as Azzam the American, was a prominent member of al Qaeda, known for making many statements on behalf of the organization. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda. Gadahn appeared in numerous videos, urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests. He also praised attacks and called for lone-wolf attacks in the United States.

A five-year-old child named Mai Zizhuo has gained attention in China for his basketball skills displayed in a viral video. He has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old. His skills have won him many fans, and some viewers are stunned by his potential.

Tom O’Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. The organization is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants MPs to set up a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. A Hacked Off spokesman said that the meeting was open to and free for all members of the public to attend.

On Thursday, Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained to serve as a catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation at Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Ten Pieces, led by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a unisex collection of ten monochrome pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Guests enjoyed refreshments from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria while watching the models walk through the concrete pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan enjoyed a family trip to a safari park in Northern California, where he posed alongside and fed a white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. He was joined by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and his daughter Lamysa. Khan also announced his next fight will be against Chris Algieri on May 30.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a Palestinian teenager, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His name appeared on the wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl for Memorial Day, but his family objected to his inclusion. Almagor, an organization that works on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, also opposed Abu Khdeir's inclusion, describing the teen's death as a rogue attack and not a terror victim. The National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial following his father's complaints, and his name has already been removed from the organization's website.

A YouTube user named Lionel Hutz filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden in a bid to get some rest. The footage shows the boy plonking himself on top of the cat, but the cat gets up and moves. The sequence happens one more time before the cat wanders off indoors. A later video shows the duo made up, and the boy is seen gently feeding the cat handfuls of treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his years selling marijuana. He told jurors that some of the undercover officers on trial had stolen cash and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Kushner also acknowledged that he was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation, and pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008.

Six people were hurt after an explosion at a chemical plant in China's southeastern Fujian province sparked a huge fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a reportedly carcinogenic chemical. Five out of six people were injured by broken glass and sent to the hospital. More than 600 firefighters were sent to battle the blaze, and the fire is now under control. The plant was hit by another explosion in July 2013, although there were no reports of casualties or toxic leaks at the time.

Aston Villa teenager Jack Grealish is renowned for keeping his stockings just above the roll of his shinpads and wears children’s shinpads. Grealish says that, due to superstition, he will continue this way. He told the BBC, "It's a superstition that I've done all my life and I'm going to keep it that way." He added, "A few referees have tried telling me but I've got to keep it like that." Grealish made his first Premier League start on Tuesday in a 3-3 draw against QPR.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Although she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Bobby Brown's attorney stated that Bobbi Kristina Brown's condition has improved, but the kind of life she will lead remains to be seen. Bobby Brown's wife, Alicia Etheredge-Brown, said that Bobbi Kristina has "started a rehabilitation that will be long and hard."

Russia is on the brink of making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova beat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, after Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges. Lisicki stated she didn't play a good tiebreaker. Russia needs one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and win a first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents are being warned to brace for more floods and damage due to another storm predicted to hit later this week, with heavy rain possible from Thursday. Meteorologists say early indicators show an east coast low could hit the region. The SES is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts, with 4,000 of 24,196 jobs still to be completed from last week's storm. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region. Bureau of Meteorology NSW Regional Director Barry Hanstrum stated that current guidance suggests rain will increase this week and peak between Thursday and Saturday.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" music video, denied claims that she tried to take her own life. She was treated in the hospital after collapsing due to low blood pressure. She posted photographs of heavy bruising on her Instagram account. Italian media reported that she tried to take her own life, but Moric said she was recovering at home after being treated in hospital on Saturday night. She explained that she fell, banging her head and hurting everywhere because of low blood pressure. Moric was shocked by the suicide claims and added that she was fine and only needed a bit of rest. Italian media claimed Ms. Moric had tried to take her own life in 2009 after taking an overdose.

As Kate and William prepare for the arrival of their second child, a new poll reveals that Diana is the favorite name if it is a girl, with 12 percent of people supporting it. Alice and Charlotte were next, each with nine percent of the vote. If the child is a boy, 13 percent of people would like him to be called James, with Alexander being the second favorite. Of the 2,200 people polled, a quarter wanted a female baby. The poll also revealed that 68 percent of people approve of William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near protesters in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied responsibility, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves has been with Barcelona for seven successful years, but has been unable to agree to a new deal with the club. The player's agent, Dinorah Santana, said her client rejected a three-year contract extension. She stated, "the negotiations are over."

Pablo Osvaldo has urged Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes the duo would be a good fit for Boca and that the fans would love to have them. He stated, "they have a bit of a south-american style and they would be perfect for boca with their abilities."

18-year-old Lewis Ferguson experienced a spectacular fall from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton, which has been widely viewed online. Despite the fall, Ferguson was back at work, mucking out stables and riding out, with only a cut on his nose. He said he was lucky and has received support and banter from other jockeys.

James Haskell showcased his inner Iron Man on Instagram with the release of the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie. The movie premiered at Westfield London shopping centre on Tuesday evening. Haskell posted an image on Thursday along with a message about the Avengers movie and releasing his inner Iron Man. He returned to the Wasps for the 2012 season after spells with Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders in New Zealand. Since returning to the Wasps, Haskell has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and has 57 caps with the England squad.

A current fashion trend is the wide-leg trouser, which offers an alternative to skinny jeans. The key to wearing wide-leg trousers is to pair them with high heels and a simple top. Proportion is important, so a simple knit, shirt, or tee keeps the look current. Denim is an easy way to adopt the trend, as seen on the Gucci SS15 runway. Topshop's Miller jean offers a 1970s-style wide-leg flare, while Celine and Stella McCartney showcased dressier-style pants.

The University of Michigan will proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" after initially canceling it due to a petition from over 200 students. E. Royster Harper, the University of Michigan's Vice President for Student Life, stated that canceling the movie was a mistake and inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression. The university will also offer a screening of "Paddington" for those who prefer not to watch "American Sniper."

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to hit a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth in Western Australia on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed. The men were questioned, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty. They will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

With help from some filmmakers, 102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer in the 1930s and 40s, was able to see herself dance for the first time. Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and some volunteers put together a video of "soundies" and showed them to Barker at her nursing home. Barker was delighted, saying, "It's just fabulous."

A study by vehicle leasing firm OSV surveyed 1,100 adults and found that the tradition of washing one's own car is declining in Britain. Key findings include: 31% of men have never washed their own car; only 5% of those surveyed had ever asked their children to wash the car; and three-quarters of women never wash their own car. Reasons for the decline include shops now opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and the large size of 4x4 and off-road vehicles. Cars are most likely to be washed by their owners every week in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield and least likely in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh.

Steven Gerrard will be leaving Liverpool for LA Galaxy, with his final match potentially being the FA Cup final against Arsenal on May 30th, which is also his birthday. Martin Skrtel praised Gerrard's impact since Skrtel arrived at Anfield in 2008, stating that Gerrard helped him settle in. Skrtel believes Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world. While Skrtel admits Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, he believes the club has potential replacements. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool lineup for the match against Villa.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus made a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Nicklaus said it was his first ace on the hallowed turf of Augusta. Camilo Villegas also made a hole-in-one on the fourth and eighth holes, but Kevin Streelman won the contest. There were five hole-in-ones on the day, leveling the record from 2002.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas due to several storms, with reported twisters near Goddard and in southwestern Kansas. CNN's severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Missouri also experienced potential tornado activity near Potosi, with reports of wind damage and flooding. Additional storms are predicted for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes. The report was contributed to by CNN's Sean Morris and AnneClaire Stapleton.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Eric Harris. Bates claims he meant to use a Taser but mistakenly shot Harris with a gun. He has been granted permission to vacation in the Bahamas, a decision that has upset Harris's family. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. There are claims that Bates was not qualified to be on the force and received preferential treatment, with allegations that some supervisors were told to forge Bates' records. Bates' lawyer released his training documents, stating they prove he had proper training.

Conor McGregor, preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11, revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach. McGregor, who already has a tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart on his chest, shared the new artwork on Instagram. He claims he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time. The pair have a fractious relationship, and during a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 supporters.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who said he was glorifying binge drinking. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, said it was problematic that the prime minister was showcasing his masculinity in this way. Opposition leader Bill Shorten joked about the incident, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Mr. Abbott, stating there was nothing wrong with his actions. Coach Simon Carradous asked Mr. Abbott to have a drink, and Mr. Abbott happily obliged.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to Scott County. The 30-day needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence on March 26 has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, with 1,400 used syringes returned. Pence is reviewing reports and will decide on extending the program beyond April 25. The outbreak is among intravenous drug users, primarily involving the painkiller Opana.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia (@saskiaisabxlla), take a test about the football club. She scored 87% (43.5 out of 50), and he graded her an 'A'. He said he would not dump her as a result. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables, and open-ended questions. Saskia struggled with some questions, including naming all 11 starting squad players and their positions. Some Twitter users hailed the boyfriend as a "legend," while others thought he had taken things too far.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked for the DEA as an undercover operative for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship, but is now facing deportation. He was a mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel in the 1980s and fled to the United States. He became one of the DEA's most important assets, aiding in the prosecution of figures such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Toro was promised US citizenship but has not received it and is now living in the US illegally. The DEA refused to help Toro with his citizenship after he went public. One of Toro's former colleagues gave him $5,000 for an operation after the DEA declined to help.

A 14-year-old girl is in critical condition with 70% burns after setting herself on fire. She was allegedly gang-raped on Sunday when she went outside her house in Kosi Kalan, in Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district. The accused men have been arrested. There is heightened sensitivity to the issue of sexual assault in India, especially after the gang rape and murder of 23-year-old student Jyoti Singh, who was attacked on a bus. Her death led to protests throughout India and outraged the world.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal dreams of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby, but will have to do so without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, who are not fit enough to play. Van Gaal wants to win because it's a big step up the table, with third place available if they win. He acknowledged that City will provide a stern challenge. Van Gaal is looking forward to sampling the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested rising ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium, leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match. Banners were displayed, with one reading, "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket". The protest followed the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14bn TV rights deal. Tickets for the game started at £64. Fan groups, such as Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, organized the event. Further protests were expected after the match.

Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. After an unsuccessful operation to unblock her bile ducts, a liver transplant became the only option. Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, donated part of her liver, saving Star's life. Star has since made a good recovery after the operation in November and spending six weeks in hospital.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian took part in Audi's football challenge. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, 5-3 and 6-0, respectively. The challenges included firing balls into the boot of a car and playing over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 plus. In the final challenge, Remy and Willian won. During the challenge, Willian smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audi cars.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed Amanda Murphy, her fiancé Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault. He stated he was not suicidal, despite prosecutors saying he told investigators he was trying to kill himself. Dellinger faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit. His attorneys claimed he was suffering from the effects of multiple conditions and medications.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt.
